TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: War and Violence-related Toys, Games and Video Games
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
(1) they are gravely concerned over the availability of war toys and other combat or violence related toys and games, including video games, in our country;
(2) they believe there is sufficient scientific evidence to show that these kind of toys and games are educationally unsound, psychologically damaging to children, and socially undesirable.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Senate will take measures to end all trading in war and violence related toys, games, and video games, through either self-regulation by the traders in these products, or legislative action.

PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care for the Elderly
PETITION.PARA: Honourable the President and members of the Senate Assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that,
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
If open not-for-profit Health Funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, those costs need to be shared equitably.
Some Health Insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to, take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all Health Funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Michael Baume (from 30 citizens), Burns (from 787 citizens), Jones (from 469 citizens) and Macklin (from 111 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Elector-initiated Referendum
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. the right of the people of a country to make law independent of politicians should be a basic and independent right;
2. consequently there is an urgent need for constitutional reforms.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should: support both the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1989 to provide a method of altering the Constitution on the initiative of electors, and the Legislative Initiative Bill 1989 to provide for the holding of referenda on bills proposed by members of the public;
and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that Senator Cook will be absent from Question Time today as he is attending a meeting of the Western Australian Iron Ore Industry Council. Any questions on his portfolio or those he represents should be directed to Senator Walsh.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the devastating impact of record interest rates on Australian home buyers and the Treasurer's admission last week that at least part of the 1 July tax cuts will have to go towards helping to meet the extra burden. Taking one of the examples mentioned in the April economic statement, a wage earner on $26,000 a year and with a dependent spouse and two children, who has been promised tax and family assistance advantage of $41 a week, I ask whether the Minister is aware that if such a person has a $50,000 unregulated home loan over 25 years, his or her mortgage repayments have gone up, in less than a year, by about $34 a week, and in the case of a $75,000 mortgage-which is by no means excessive these days-the increase exceeds $50 a week. In other words, does the Minister agree that the crippling interest rates flowing from his Government's economic policy have, for hundreds of thousands of Australians, wiped out the benefits from the tax cuts before they have even been received?

—Even Senator Patterson's own figures do not establish that proposition; but of course the Government is aware of the impact of high interest rates on certain home owners. I have not done the figures to which Senator Patterson referred in her question; I am not in a position to either accept or dispute those figures. I accept them as having been put forward in good faith. The fact is that tax cuts given at any time are eroded in certain circumstances by inflation, or by mortgage repayments, or whatever. The tax cuts will, however, remain. It is the Government's hope that the high level of home loan mortgage rates will not remain.
—Is Hawke's statement still operative? Have we had a fall this year?

—I do not know about that. In answer to the honourable senator's question I will repeat what I have said on a number of occasions. The Government regrets the high level of home loan mortgage rates and the fact that they are a burden on a sector of the community. But, of course, the tax cuts are of universal benefit.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. I refer to remarks made yesterday by the shadow Treasurer, Dr John Hewson, that the Opposition aimed to cut spending on social security. Is it possible to make major savings on social security outlays without affecting either eligibility for payment or the level of benefits paid?
—How is your family allowance looking?

—I will not have to sell the Ferrari, do not worry. Will the Government be making any changes which will dramatically reduce the number of people eligible for pensions and benefits, and the level at which pensions and benefits are paid?

—In response to the first question, it is, by definition, not possible to make savings on social security outlays without either affecting the eligibility-making changes which withdraw eligibility-or lowering the rate to some or all. A further danger is that if an attempt were made to do that by restricting eligibility to a particular entitlement, there would be a risk that people might transfer to some other entitlement. But it is not possible, by definition, to make savings unless we either withdraw the entitlement that some people have or reduce the rate that some or all receive. I was particularly interested in Dr Hewson's reference to tighter targeting, and to note the total contradiction between that and Mr Peacock's statement made in 1984 in his only election campaign as Leader of the Opposition when he proposed effectively to abolish targeting altogether and to provide, at least in the long term, universal entitlement. In 1984 he was promising to abolish the assets test. That test is currently saving $500m or $600m a year. Dr Hewson talks about tighter targeting. What does the Opposition stand for? Does it stand for no targeting or tighter targeting?
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. The Minister has again moved into his debating mode. I ask you to call him to order and ask him to answer the question and cease debating the matter.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Minister was answering the question.

—Mr President, I would like to address that point of order. There is a standing order which quite clearly says that Ministers will not debate the question. I ask you, in giving your ruling, to indicate what that means if what the Minister was doing then was not debating the question. He had moved away from any direct answer to the question asked and was undertaking a general debate which included attacking the now Leader of the Opposition for his 1984 position. I suggest to you, Mr President, that if that standing order has any meaning at all, the Minister has infringed it.
—In reply to the point of order: Senator Walsh did move away from the question he was asked but he returned to it. That was why I allowed him to continue.

—I want to make two other points. The first-a legitimate point, I suppose-is that 1984 was a long time ago. Now that the souffle has risen again, perhaps it has also changed its view of the world. However, I refer those who are interested to the Opposition's social security policy issued towards the end of 1988 which still proposed a very substantial relaxation of the assets test which would have impeded the sort of structural adjustment that is required in agriculture as well. As to the final part of the question, the Government certainly will not be taking advice from merchant-banking, restaurant-owning, yuppie, Ferrari-driving shadow treasurers about who is needy and who is not.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TREASURER: VISIT TO THE SOVIET UNION

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade why the Treasurer is visiting the Soviet Union. Will the Minister provide the Senate with details of the Treasurer's itinerary and estimates of the costs of the trip?
—I will take the question on notice.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade is apparently not aware that his Treasurer has gone to the Soviet Union. We are seeking details of the itinerary in the Soviet Union and estimates of the costs. I will now ask specific questions about the trip. Is it a fact that the visit to the Soviet Union was privately organised by the Treasurer's ministerial office and not by any Government department-not even by the Treasury? Can the Minister confirm-I believe it is the Minister's responsibility-that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade first learned of the Treasurer's Soviet visit from the Australian Embassy in Moscow, which has expressed its frustration and concern about the fact that the itinerary and arrangements were organised without its involvement? Can the Minister also confirm that, besides Moscow and Leningrad, the Treasurer will be visiting a number of other places in the Soviet Union which hold no direct relevance for any Australian Government business at all? Is it a fact that the common link between the Treasurer's various ports of call in the Soviet Union is their significance as trading centres for Empire period antiques?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason I chose to take the question on notice was that at that stage I had no details of the itinerary that the Treasurer was following and only the most general knowledge of the purpose of his visit. That is not in the slightest bit unusual. Ministers are constantly travelling for good reason, just as they did during the Fraser era, the McMahon era, the Holt era and the Gorton era-on a significantly greater scale, incidentally, than is the case these days. There is no reason whatsoever why my Department or I, as Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, should be expected to know off the top of my head what the circumstances are of a particular visit of a particular Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: But as it turns out, since I have been given the courtesy of a supplementary question by Senator Lewis, I am now able to answer with some precision what the circumstances are. There is no need for me to take that part of the question on notice. The Treasurer is taking up a longstanding invitation from the Soviet Government to visit the Soviet Union. His time in Leningrad will be mainly over a weekend from late Friday, 2 June, until he departs for Moscow early on Tuesday, 6 June. He will be making official calls in that time. The arrangements are in the hands of the Soviet authorities.

In Moscow the Treasurer will address the Institute of International Relations on the international economy. He will meet members of that institute. He will meet with the committee on Soviet industry and economic reconstruction. Appointments have also been sought with the central committee of the Soviet Communist Party and a range of other Soviet representatives. Precise meetings will depend upon the appointment this week by the Supreme Soviet of the Prime Minister and Ministers of the Soviet Government. Of course the identification of appointees has been in issue pending that meeting of the Supreme Soviet this week.

May I conclude by saying that it is entirely appropriate that Australia should continue to develop high level links with the Soviet Union consistent with not only our foreign policy interests but also our national economic interests, and of course not least in order to keep before our eyes a detailed current understanding of the important changes which are occurring in Soviet policy. There is no question whatsoever of anything other than the most ample and substantial justification for the Treasurer's visit to the Soviet Union. As a result the question is totally misconceived.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Justice been referred to an article in the Brisbane Courier-Mail headed `Asia Inquiries on Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen'? Does this article claim that investigators from the Fitzgerald Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct have been to Singapore and Hong Kong to probe the financial affairs of former Premier Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen? Has any request been made from either the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct or the team of four Queensland detectives led by top fraud investigator Inspector John Huey for assistance in this matter of the National Crime Authority or the Australian Federal Police and, if so, has it been forthcoming?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have with me the press article to which Senator Jones referred in his question which has to do with inquiries being undertaken, according to the article, by the Fitzgerald inquiry. It would not be for me to have any knowledge of those inquiries as they are operational matters that are still being undertaken by Mr Fitzgerald in the course of the last several weeks of his inquiry and apparently contemporaneously with his drawing up of his report.

ANSWER.PARA: In reply to the part of the question dealing with the particular assistance afforded to him by national law enforcement agencies, let me say that it is a fact that the National Crime Authority has, from the very beginning, partly because it had a reference which coincided in part with areas of inquiry that Mr Fitzgerald wished to follow, been of great assistance to Mr Fitzgerald. Mr Fitzgerald has called upon the Australian Federal Police and several members of it in particular to give him assistance in pursuing certain lines of inquiry and, indeed, in drawing up his report. Commonwealth law enforcement agencies have been extremely helpful at every stage and have responded to every request from Mr Fitzgerald during the course of his investigations which are so important to Queensland in relation to its own law enforcement agencies and the propriety of the conduct of both elected and non-elected public officials.

I would hope that, in acknowledgments that Mr Fitzgerald does make, in the course of his final report, he will pay tribute to the national law enforcement agencies which have been of assistance to him. As to whether any such assistance has been afforded in respect of the particular inquiries which it is alleged are being undertaken in Asian countries, I have no information that I can give to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to an article by Michael Short in a recent edition of the Age. The article was headed `Banks may not be villain on rates' and makes, among others, the following points: bank profits are not particularly high in Australia either compared with international banks or in relation to other Australian businesses; the six-monthly increases in profit of 52 per cent and 37 per cent for National Australia Bank Ltd and Westpac Banking Corporation respectively are `huge and meaningless numbers unless related to . . . the return each company earns for its shareholders'; and if it were possible for mortgage rates to be lower, would not government banks such as the State Bank of Victoria be making them lower? Does the Minister agree with the assessment made by Mr Short in that article? In particular, does the Minister believe that the responsibility for the current interest rate crisis lies more with the Government's economic policies than with the banks or does he believe that one or more external factor outside the control of either government or the banks is responsible? Finally, does the Minister agree that the current high interest rate regime offers very little to depositors after their interest earnings have been hit by income and provisional taxes, and is a major problem for small business, rural producers and home buyers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the last part of the question concerning interest earnings, let me say that, whatever change should be made to the taxation treatment of interest payments, if the objective is to increase savings or change the mix between savings and consumption, one thing that the Government will not do is follow the crude, populist line or posturing of the likes of Senator Haines who brought in a private member's Bill to exempt the first $2,000 of income, because the effect of that, for the reasons I explained to her in some detail when her silly Bill was before the Senate, would be a reduced savings effort, that is, a big reduction in public savings for a possible small increase in private savings.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the rest of the question, I did not see the Age article. I was, however, aware of the fact that some banks-I think the two named by Senator Haines were the National Australia Bank and Westpac-had reported large percentage increases in their profits for this period compared to the previous period. I am not sure whether the previous period was a 12-month or a six-month period. Senator Haines said that those increased profits amounted to 52 per cent and 37 per cent respectively. I was asked whether they are meaningless. They are certainly not meaningless because, assuming the figures are correct, it means they are 52 per cent and 37 per cent respectively higher than for the previous period. If one looks beyond that, they are not particularly meaningful unless they are measured against the size of the investment, and I do not know what that is. As to the State Bank of Victoria, I would have thought that it would have enough trouble dealing with the fall-out from the Victorian Division of the National Safety Council of Australia without adding anything else to its plate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. In view of the widespread concern by pensioner organisations about increases in health insurance costs of up to $35 a week, as reported in yesterday's Sun-Herald newspaper, what action is available to the Government to avert a major crisis in the affordability of aged health care?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a note on this, but I do not seem to be able to find it. I know the essential points, anyway.
—Put them in order.

—Put what in order? I will put Senator Boswell in order again with a bit of wire if he gives too much cheek. The Government is currently trying to legislate for the protection of the community rating principle by expanding the reinsurance pool to cover hospital costs, including supplementary benefits, from the time of admission to hospital for all people aged 65 and over. That will relieve the pressure on those funds which have a disproportionate number of older contributors. The Government believes that it is only fair that health funds should compete on a level playing field, that they should not be allowed to pick and choose their clients in such a way that required some funds to charge ever-increasing premiums while other funds charged ever decreasing premiums, if they were skilful enough at selecting their client group.

ANSWER.PARA: It is completely beyond me why the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have opposed that legislation. The point of Senator Faulkner's question concerns the effect that this will have on aged people. If the Opposition and the Democrats persist with their misconceived plans to block this legislation the premiums paid by aged people for health insurance will go up, to the point where a very much smaller number of them will be able to afford health insurance. All the significant age pensioner organisations are well aware of that fact. The Government has the support of, among other groups, the Australian Pensioners Federation, the Australian Council on the Ageing, the Australian Retired Persons Association and the Combined Pensioners Association of New South Wales. Even Grey Power-I think `geriatric fascists' was the term used by Senator Haines-is supporting this move.

The pensioners have seen what the consequences of this misconceived action would be. They are rightly dismayed and outraged about the action the Opposition and the Democrats propose to take. I am informed that the 8,000 pensioners in the seat of Kingston are already campaigning against Senator Haines on this issue. I predict that it will not be very long, once Senator Haines gets the message from the 8,000 pensioners in Kingston, before she backs down on it. If she is not too concerned about the pensioners of Kingston, I would have thought that she would pay some attention to the first paragraph in today's editorial in the major newspaper in her State-that, of course being the Adelaide Advertiser. Under the heading `Politics threatens care of the Aged', the article said:

The coalition Opposition and the Democrats will show today whether they care more for people or for playing politics. They have threatened to combine and delay legislation intended to reform health insurance by forcing it into a Senate committee.

The 8,000 pensioners in Kingston and the two million, or thereabouts, in other parts of Australia are well aware of what the Opposition and the Democrats are up to and are well aware of what the consequences for pensioners will be if they persist in, yet again, using the Senate to obstruct the passage of necessary legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It concerns increasing interest rates, which are affecting a lot of people-many more than was indicated by Senator Walsh in reply to the last question. I note Senator Button's refusal on Friday to speculate on interest rates, virtually at the same time as the National Australia Bank and the Westpac Banking Corporation announced home mortgage rates of 17 per cent, with some suggestions that 18 per cent is not out of the question. Does the Government require any further demonstration of the fact that its policies are not sustainable and must be changed, or does it assert that a home loan interest rate of 17 per cent, or even higher, and rates in excess of 20 per cent for overdrafts, which so vitally affect small businesses, are an acceptable part of an appropriate mix of policies?

—On this issue, I have very little to add to what I said on Friday, when I was asked a question in the context of the publication of the national accounts figures for the quarter ending in March. In answer, I said that there was some evidence, since the period covered by those figures, of a slowing in the economy. That, I believe, is due largely to monetary policy, which will be maintained until the desired result is achieved.

—I have a supplementary question, Mr President. Basically, the Minister has avoided the question. Currently we have a very high interest rate of 17 per cent for home loans, and higher rates for overdrafts. These rates are related directly to the Government's choice of economic policy. Does the Minister defend them as being an acceptable part of an appropriate mix of policies?

—As Government spokesmen have said on a number of occasions, for the time being high interest rates have to be a part of the Government's strategy for dealing with excess demand in the Australian economy. Whether in the light of likely excess demand, tax cuts are undesirable is an important aspect of policy on which the Government's view is now shared by the Opposition. In that mix, interest rates remain very important.

—My question is directed to Senator Walsh in his capacity as Minister for Finance and as Minister representing the Treasurer. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —According to the national accounts, there are significant variations, in the proportion of income derived from pensions, benefits and related payments, between the national average and the figures for a number of States. In South Australia almost 16 per cent, which was the highest of all the States, came from that source. In Tasmania it was also nearly 16 per cent. The State with the lowest figure of household income from that source was Victoria with 11 1/2 per cent. But the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) was lower still with just under 5 per cent. ANSWER.PARA: If the policy enunciated by the honourable member for Wentworth, Dr Hewson, yesterday were to be implemented by the present Opposition should it get into government, firstly, it is very clear that all low income people-poor people, if one wants to use that term-throughout Australia would be adversely affected. The greatest impact would be on the States of South Australia, Tasmania and Queensland. The least impact would be on those parts of the country which are already the most prosperous, namely, Victoria and the ACT.

I suggest that it is quite properly a matter of legitimate concern to Senator Burns, as a representative of Queensland, and also a matter of concern to those people who purport to represent Tasmania and South Australia, that Dr Hewson be firmly told that he should not proceed with his program. However, Dr Hewson will have difficulty if he is not allowed to proceed with his program of cutting the entitlements or rates that people receive, particularly if he has to fund the ambitious plans of Senator Newman and many smaller or lesser lights in the Opposition to spend a great deal more money elsewhere.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF CHINA: DEVELOPMENT IMPORT FINANCE FACILITY SCHEME

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is it a fact that contracts worth millions of dollars with the People's Republic of China are being held up because the Government has allocated insufficient funds to the development import finance facility (DIFF) scheme? Is it a fact that the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau has told Australian companies that no new offers under the DIFF scheme can be made until the 1990-91 financial year? Is the Minister aware that this is creating enormous problems for Australian companies which have responded to the Government's exhortations to develop overseas markets? Is the Minister further aware that there is considerable disenchantment on the part of the Chinese who, after signing contracts subject to DIFF finance with Australian companies, are being asked to wait 12 months or more before the contracts can be further progressed? In view of the obvious benefits to our consistently disastrous balance of payments, will the Minister take steps immediately to ensure that DIFF has enough funds to support Australian companies which have secured exports contracts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would certainly like to ensure that enough funds were available under the DIFF scheme, not only to support all possible and conceivable contracts that might satisfy its criteria to China but also, indeed, to elsewhere. But, as Senator Hill and the Opposition ought to be aware, in these circumstances one has to balance the advantages that flow to the external trade account from contracts of this kind against the fiscal downside that is involved in an ever expanding contribution to the DIFF component of the aid budget. That has got further problems in an environment where it is difficult to keep the aid budget growing at the level at which we would want it to grow in terms of aid policy generally, quite apart from the commercial spin-offs that are involved.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, my understanding of the present situation so far as Chinese contracts are concerned is that all existing DIFF commitments will be able to be satisfied in the forthcoming financial year; that is to say, contracts in respect of which formal offers have been made and in respect of which contracts either have been formally signed or are about to be, pursuant to those formal offers. It may be, depending on the budgetary outcome, that any new formal offers that are made next financial year 1989-90, and are subject to new contracts being entered into during the course of financial year 1989-90, might not be able to be the subject of draw down from the Government Treasury until financial year 1990-91. But we are talking about contracts that have yet to be entered into, rather than those that are already, as it were, at the stage of about to be implemented.

More generally, there have been claims that Australia is missing out on commercial opportunities in China. But those claims ignore the reality of Australia's trade with China and the very considerable effort that the Government has been investing in promoting trade and two-way investment between the two countries. Two-way trade between Australia and China has grown substantially from $A720m in 1983 to $1.9 billion in 1988. Obviously regular high level visits by leaders and Ministers of both countries have helped to advance commercial interests as well as the political and multilateral ones. Government to government consultative arrangements have been established in a number of specific sectors, including wool, iron and steel, non-ferrous metals, coal, transport and communications, machinery, and electronics products. We have of course got major Chinese investments in two very large resource-based projects in Australia, the Channar iron ore mine and the Portland aluminium smelter, while a range of Australian companies has been establishing joint ventures in China to gain a foothold into the Chinese market and to operate as a platform for export to third countries.

Current events in China notwithstanding, the Government will continue its efforts to enhance trade relations with China and to help the Australian private sector identify opportunities in China. We will continue to support financially, as best we can, through the DIFF program such commercial exercises in terms of contracting for major development oriented tenders. But necessarily the extent to which that support is available will have to depend on budgetary considerations, as those opposite will find out if they ever, God help the country, get the chance to try to apply these principles in practice. It is very easy to make promise after promise for sector after sector, commercial or otherwise, about what they will do by way of funding these intrinsically desirable, wholesome and admirable objectives. But they cannot do that while they are simultaneously claiming that very large sums ought to be chopped from the Commonwealth Budget. They cannot have their cake and eat it too. It is about time they woke up to that and about time the people who got suckered into believing that they are capable of delivering across the range of issues where they do make these promises, woke up to what it is they are about.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I draw the Minister's attention to weekend statements by the shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson, that a future coalition government would cut into the social security budget. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether this Government should make such economies; which groups in the community would be adversely affected; and what such steps would mean to the goal of creating a fairer and more equitable Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset in answering Senator Foreman's question I think it should be made very clear that the Government rejects such a broad sweep approach as has been advocated by the Opposition in the social welfare area. This particular area highlights the differences between the Government's constructed, targeted policy in this area compared to the sweeping, damaging rhetoric of the Opposition. The Opposition policy is one that is clearly not acceptable to the Government. In saying that, I should say that the Government's approach to social security has been based on maintaining the integrity of the system while ensuring that assistance does in fact go to those most in need. At the same time the Government is concerned about breaking down the barriers to employment. For instance, the jobs, employment and training program and the Newstart program are two specific programs which are geared towards helping sole parents and long term unemployed overcome particular barriers to work force participation. The underlying commitment of this Government, which is one that we maintain very strongly, is to those groups in the community for which there is an acceptable level of dependency, such as the aged and the disabled.

ANSWER.PARA: The alternative approach-the one that has been espoused increasingly over recent days by the Opposition-is one that is born out of ignorance and expediency. The Opposition just does not understand. It has said it will slash, but it should be placed on record that out of convenience it has refused to say where it will slash. It is fair to ask, as Senator Foreman does, which areas would be under the hammer under Opposition policy.

If we are looking at those areas where major inroads can be achieved we are looking at four or five major ones. The questions the Opposition has to answer and the questions the Government has rejected in this area are questions such as these: Will the target be the 1.7 million age and service pensioners in Australia; will the target be the family allowance payments which are made to nearly two million families with more than 3.8 million children in this country; or will the target be payments for 1.2 million children in 530,000 low income families in this country? Does Dr Hewson look to tighten the income test? Will he, through the back door approach, abolish tax and fringe benefit concessions for age pensioners? The Opposition has a responsibility to spell out precisely what it is thinking in these areas, not only for the general economic good of this country but also for the direct need, security and interests of those who would be targets under any such Opposition policy.

What we have here is also an indication of a policy born out of ignorance and lack of understanding of what has happened in the social security system over the past six years. For the sake of the record the Senate needs to know that. Since 1983 social security outlays have fallen from 6.9 per cent of gross domestic product to 6.2 per cent in 1987-88 to a projected 6 per cent this year. There has been a major shift there. In terms of proportion of real Budget outlays they have decreased from 24.1 per cent in 1983-84 to 23 per cent this year. Another important part of the Government's achievement is that since 1983 the proportion of pensioners and beneficiaries has fallen from 41.9 per 100 people in the labour force to 35.2.

One reason why we reject the proposal floated over the weekend is that it would destroy substantially the work of the past seven years that this Government has been forced to undertake because of the destructive legacy from those before us. We also reject it because it would imperil one basic achievement of this Government. One of the most basic parts of social security in our society is employment. When we came to office 600,000 people were receiving unemployment benefits. At the moment we are in a position where 400,000 people receive the unemployment benefit. There is nothing more basic to helping those in need than providing employment. The sorts of destructive and ill thought out policies that have been floated over the weekend would do nothing more than imperil this Government's achievements in the social security area, which society recognises have been major. It would also imperil some major parts of those achievements which relate directly to decreasing barriers to work force participation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION: FUNDING

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen a report in Saturday's Melbourne Age under the by-line of the winner of the 1989 Michael Daly Prize for Science Reporting in the Print Media, that is, Mr Graeme O'Neill, which confirms the Government's misleading funding figures for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO)? It is correct that the Government, in calculating the funding figure for the CSIRO in 1987-88, omitted to make an allowance for the inflation rate? Is the 1987-88 funding figure therefore artificially low and does it not make the projected funding for successive years, which are all represented in 1988-89 dollars, appear more generous in comparison? As a result of the misleading base figure for 1987-88, is it not a fact that CSIRO will be worse off over the next three years than it was last year? Who is responsible for this error in basic arithmetic, or did the Government intentionally use a misleading base figure so as to give the mistaken impression that funding for the CSIRO was escalating, when in fact it was decreasing in real terms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding of this matter is that it is not the funding estimates which were flawed, but rather the information which was supplied to the journalist Graeme O'Neill. Figures circulated to journalists at the release of the May science statement were not, in the view of the Government, flawed. They were supplied for CSIRO's appropriation in 1987-88 terms, while the amounts given for the years 1988-89 to 1991-92 were in 1988-89 dollars. It is standard practice to make comparisons between budgetary figures from different years in nominal terms. It should be noted that the figures quoted for the 1989-90 year and the two subsequent years are in 1988-89 dollars and thus will need to be inflated by the CPI figures in those years.

ANSWER.PARA: To say that is not to deny that the Government has progressively decreased the CSIRO's appropriation budget over the past six years. These reductions were part of a policy of making the CSIRO more reliant on externally generated revenue. I should also point out that decisions by the Government in March this year provided CSIRO with an additional $5m for equipments for this current year and allowed CSIRO to retain all its external earnings, thereby adding a further $2.1m to its budget this year, $6.5m next year and $11.6m in 1990-91. When combined with the additional $90m provided for CSIRO in the May statement over the next five years, this reflects a substantial increase in funds since the August 1988 Budget in the Government's contribution to the Organisation.

Senator McGauran also put a couple of smaller parts in his question. I would make the point that the CSIRO budget position was considered at recent board and executive committees of the Organisation. A three-year budget is now being finalised and will allow for substantially increased flexibility to accommodate resource and priority changes, which are determined by the board of CSIRO in consultation with management.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is of the Minister for Finance while he is in such good form. I refer to the statement by the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia that the Government had made `a major miscalculation' in understanding the power of the economy. What hope can the Government now hold out to home buyers, small businesses and farmers who are now suffering because of the Government's bungled economic policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was expecting to be asked such a question although I thought it would be a more wide-ranging question from Senator Stone, Senator MacGibbon's Queensland Opposition colleague. In fact, I was expecting it last Friday from Senator Stone and then again today, but I note that Senator Stone is not in the chamber. I assume that Senator MacGibbon is filling in for him.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen Mr Johnston's comments. I do not know what I can say other than that Mr Johnston admitted that he and the Reserve Bank had misjudged the likely or actual strength of the economic growth that was under way. It is fairly clear that almost everybody did. Anybody who gets into the business of forecasting, whether it is weather forecasting or economic forecasting, is bound to make mistakes. Even Senator Stone made a spectacular mistake with his not so much a forecast as an edict issued in October 1987 that there would be a world recession in 1988. Senator Stone was spectacularly wrong about that. Governments make mistakes about economic forecasts and bankers make mistakes in forecasting economic outcomes. The Australian Financial Review from time to time publishes what is said by leading private sector forecasters, some of whom are bankers and some of whom are representatives of stockbroking firms, and they are sometimes spectacularly wrong on things such as foreign exchange rates 12 months hence.

The Government has admitted that we did not realise that the underlying economic growth was as strong and therefore that the pressures on the economy were as strong. That pressure comes from two sources, the same two from which it always comes, I suppose. They are consumption spending, which has been quite high, and investment spending, which has been at incredibly high levels. That level of investment spending, according to the figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics today, is expected to hold into the next six-monthly period, in spite of, I suppose one could say, the high interest rates.

Adjustments have been made. We are continuing with the tight monetary policy. The Reserve Bank of Australia, as Senator MacGibbon would know, increased its rediscount rate last week by something like 0.3 of one per cent. Some of the bankers-perhaps I should say some of the economic commentators who speak about this issue, including the shadow Treasurer-have also warned that a tight monetary policy, if held in place for too long, might overshoot, and that is a danger. Nobody can be certain that he is correct about when it is appropriate to relax that monetary policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I express the thanks of the Senate to have an admission of failure and error from Senator Walsh.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 May Senator Chapman asked me a question, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, regarding the rates charged by hire car operators in Canberra. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed that the answer to Senator Chapman's question is as follows: No. The rates charged by hire car firms in the ACT for services provided to the Commonwealth result from quotes made by hire car firms in competitive tenders. The contract between the Commonwealth and the hire car firms includes an annual percentage increase to the contract rates. There is provision for contractors to waive the right to this percentage increase. No contractor has waived the right to the first percentage increase in the current period. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Government to ensure a flexible and efficient working environment on the Australian waterfront through lasting and genuine reforms, including the introduction of full enterprise employment, appropriate changes in union coverage and the elimination of restrictive work practices.

At a time when there is a heavy legislative program, the Opposition is reluctant to add items of business. However, after the economic news of the last few weeks, and in view of the clear difficulties faced by Australia, as well as by its working men and women, it is vital to draw to the Government's attention some of the areas in which it could take action that would do something to relieve our predicament. The context of this debate is one in which we have a frightening level of international debt. Our debt will continue to rise, not only because of the decline in the value of the dollar, but also because the fundamentals of our economy are so wrong.

The national accounts bringing us to up to the March quarter, which were published just last week, show that, by comparison with the previous 12 months, in real terms, our exports of goods and services declined by over 3 per cent, and our imports rose by 29.6 per cent. That is the situation that Australia finds itself in, and clearly it is a very serious one. But the people of Australia are affected more directly by the other policies that flow from the Government's failure to cope with the external situation. Most of all, the people of Australia are affected by high interest rates, which, for home buyers, have now reached 17 per cent and threaten to go to 18 per cent, and, for other borrowers, including small businesses and farmers, have gone to much higher levels.

I do not think that one can encapsulate the human element of the predicament in which Australia now finds itself better than by going back to a matter that was debated a month or so ago, when we were looking at the capacity of Australians to buy their own homes. Young Australian couples are being told by lending authorities that if they postpone their childbearing by 10 years they might be able to get a housing loan. Young married couples wanting to buy a house are being told that a 10-year delay in starting a family is a condition of their getting the funds to buy a home. There could be no clearer demonstration of the fact that the Government has adopted in its economic management an approach that is thoroughly destructive of everything that this country previously stood for.

The question of the waterfront is relevant to all those matters. If one looks at the problem that we face, and at the Government's own diagnosis of it, one sees that this country is simply not productive enough. It is not an Opposition shibboleth to say that Australia needs to produce more; it is a view that has been put forward by Mr Keating, who, before he went off on his junket to Paris and his junket to Russia-and we have had no adequate explanation of those junkets at a time of economic crisis-said:
There is really only one message that can be drawn from our current circumstances . . . It is, simply, that our current account deficit is too high because we are spending more than we can produce.

We have also referred in debate in the Senate to what the Governor of the Reserve Bank had to say. He talked about our predicament in very similar terms. He talked about Australians living in a state of self-indulgence, which is a pretty extraordinary thing to say when Australian home buyers are paying 17 per cent on their mortgages. Mr Johnston was making the same point as the Treasurer, that we are consuming more than we produce and that if we are to solve our problems we need to be more productive. Indeed, in that speech which received so much publicity, Mr Johnston said that the economy would improve only if we provided conditions in which Australia could get on with constructive policies to improve the balance of payments. He added:
This highlights the urgency of shifting resources into export and import competing industries and improving productivity and cost performance.
There is no escaping the imperative that, if we are to get Australia out of its terrible mess, we have to become a more productive country.

Every Australian knows that the waterfront is an area of gross waste. I doubt that there is a man, woman or child, other than a child of very tender years, who does not know that the waterfront is one of the causes of our impoverishing Australia. It is an area where there is gross waste and where the attempts of Australians to improve productivity through exporting goods and services or importing necessary goods are impeded by the expensive shenanigans that go on on our waterfront. They are shenanigans which involve not just trade unionists but often employers as well. We have extensive documentation of the problems of the Australian waterfront. We have been told in this massive report of the Inter-State Commission some of the things which could be done to do away with some $650m-worth of waste, inefficiency and unnecessary costs adding to the personal burdens of Australians throughout the community.

The Government has been given a blueprint for reform and change. It is not a blueprint that we think goes far enough, but it is one that we think would take the industry substantially down the road towards real reform. What do we find the Government doing? We find that the Government is prevaricating. Our object in bringing forward this debate today is to repeat the offer which I made on behalf of the Opposition last week: our complete cooperation with the Government to solve these problems. Once again, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, who has not said a serious thing about the economy in the Senate for a very long time, giggles his way through Question Time and now through this debate because he has the belief that the Government, of which he is a part, no longer has the capacity to deliver fundamental reform, no longer has any life expectancy and no longer has the guts and the determination which are required to make the necessary changes within Australia. Senator Button and his Government seem to be paralysed. We, in the Opposition, are saying that we are not the reason why the Government is paralysed. We are prepared to offer our fullest cooperation in the Parliament, both with respect to the necessary changes in the law and to appropriating moneys which are required to complete this plan, because we believe that it is vitally important for Australia.

What is the response of the Government? Does the Government say, `Thank you, we agree that this is an urgent problem that should be fixed in Australia's national interest.'? Of course it does not. The Government is locked away in meetings with the trade union movement and with employers desperately trying to work its way through its usual conundrum. How can it make the fundamental reforms which are necessary in Australia without the support of the trade union movement, which tends to have a rather negative view about reforms which will affect the power and influence of that movement? This report is a very useful, objective and non-political summary of what is wrong with our waterfront and why there is a need for change. We are told that there is ineffective management; poor work force training and career arrangements; introspective industrial attitudes; poor response to user needs-in other words, the customer can go to hell; the consumer is not regarded-poor information flows; lack of supply and demand balance; a tendency for matters to improve while they are under investigation but to lapse once the pressure is removed; and an abuse of monopoly power, reflected particularly in port authority pricing and investment policies. These are a whole lot of things which are to be fixed. We call upon the Government to do it, and to do it as a matter of urgency, not because it is important for its own sake, but because it is important if we are to solve the economic problems of Australia. This non-political report says:

To this litany can be added high costs, endemic unreliability, a high level of industrial disputation, inappropriate manning levels and work practices, poor discipline, poor motivation throughout the industry, and a pervasive lack of competition.

That expression, `a pervasive lack of competition', really does get to the heart of the matter. If we look at the areas of inefficiency and waste in the Australian economy, the areas which are causing our lack of productivity, which in turn is causing the high interest rates which are bedevilling virtually every Australia, they are all in areas where there is a lack of competition. The Inter-State Commission report sets out to ensure that our waterfronts are forced to act in a more competitive way, because the Commission has made a statement in this report which I think is fundamentally important if we are to tackle any of these areas of structural inefficiency in the Australian economy. The Commission says:
. . . the Commission has . . . made recommendations designed to preserve competition once the artificial constraints are removed.

One might ask why that is important. Well, it is important because the pattern of change on the waterfront is like the pattern of change of so much in Australia. There have been 12 inquiries into the waterfront. Many of those inquiries have resulted in changes, but the effect of each inquiry and the effect of each change has been to leave us where we were before-no competition and hence a situation where restrictive work practices, waste and inefficiency flourish.

The key thing about the Opposition's approach to this, and the key elements of this report which lead us to support it, are that it is putting forward proposals which will lead to genuine competition on the waterfront and which will force people to change as circumstances change and to remain efficient. What we are talking about is an industry where it is common ground that the waste is in excess of $600m. The Business Council of Australia says it is over $800m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Direct waste.

—Direct, as Senator Parer, who will be participating in this debate a little later, says-$800m of direct waste. We could add over $1 billion to the wealth available in this country if we could only get an efficient waterfront. That is the simple proposition we are seeking. I know that the Minister who is now at the table, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, who I am rather sorry was translated into Foreign Affairs, when he was Minister for Transport and Communications knew that, if we were to turn Australia around, we had to come to grips with these areas of waste and inefficiency. He was a Minister with some stomach for it, but now we have Ministers like Willis and Morris, who have no stomach for any reform or change which does not have the blessing of the trade union people who might suffer some short term ill-effect from it. We have lost the impetus for reform in this country under the current Ministers. I am very sorry that has happened, because it is costing Australia dear, including 17 per cent and 18 per cent interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: We find that the trade union movement has made it clear that it is extremely doubtful about some of these areas of fundamental change. In a statement on 22 May, just a few days ago, the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia (WWF) Acting General Secretary, John Coombs, said that the union would never budget on the issues of withdrawal of coverage from small ports and container depots, the inclusion of automatic stand-down provisions in awards, compulsory redundancy, the contracting out of work and the use of casuals.

When we reel off the things the union is opposed to, I suppose the average listener asks: Does it matter? Are these things that the union is objecting to serious? Let me therefore quickly focus on one of the things that the Waterside Workers Federation is objecting to. Do honourable members know it has been found that our ports are about half as efficient as the ports of the countries that we compete with? When we look at this area of coverage of the Waterside Workers Federation and look at how that affects the packing and unpacking of containers, we get a perfect illustration of why change is needed and why the Waterside Workers Federation's interest is not the national interest, it is not the interest of the people of Australia, because we can test it from current practice.

Some containers are loaded on premises which are covered by the Waterside Workers Federation and others are packed on premises which are covered by the Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia. In other words, we have the chance to compare the packing and unpacking of containers in areas where the Waterside Workers Federation is involved and in areas where it is not. The simple reality is that in those areas where there is WWF coverage the rate of packing and unpacking is sadly much lower than the rate where there is other union coverage. There is a very interesting account in the Business Review Weekly of 26 May of a courageous businessman who is trying to fight this area of waste and inefficiency. It is pointed out in that article that these packing restrictions go back to 1967. It is the great old Australian way, having these sorts of restrictions. We find that, where the WWF is involved, the cost of packing a container runs to more than $600, but the cost elsewhere is less than $400. In other words, there is an extra couple of hundred dollars just for the privilege of being forced into a depot that is manned by the WWF instead of by the Transport Workers Union of Australia or the Storemen and Packers Union.

That is a small example of what this argument on union coverage is about. It is about whether we are going to continue to do things wastefully and inefficiently and tell the people of Australia to go to hell. That is what we are being told, `You, the people of Australia, you the consumers who are paying this extra $650m or $800m, whatever figure one likes to agree with, can just go jump in the lake, because the fact of the matter is that our union coverage is what counts, not the interests of the people, not the interests of the firms and the consumers who are affected, but the interests of the union against the interests of a different union. The WWF should have superior rights to the Transport Workers Union or the Storemen and Packers Union just because it is there'.

That is how foolish it is, and it is that sort of pressure that a government, which has Ministers like Willis and Morris in it, will not withstand. We will never solve the economic problems of Australia unless the Ministers in this Government are prepared to have the courage to act in the national interest and not in the sectional interest. I call upon the Government to avail itself of the clear and straightforward offer of cooperation which we, the Opposition, have made. We will pass the legislation through the Parliament. We will support the appropriation for the necessary funds, because we think that reform in this area is absolutely vital and in the interests of Australia. Let me make it quite clear: we are not prepared to support any reform which is not fundamental. My definition of fundamental should be clear from what I have already had to say. We insist on those reforms which at a minimum at least are the product of the report of the Inter-State Commission-we would like to go further-reforms which will guarantee that there is genuine competition on the waterfront. Labour market reform itself is essential. We are prepared to see $150m or more of taxpayers' money used to buy out the thousands of waterside workers who should be retired because they are no longer an effective and efficient part of the work force. We are prepared to pay-the people of Australia will have to pay of course-huge sums of money to get those people out of the industry so that it can work efficiently. But we will not support the payment of that money unless it is part of a pattern which entitles employers to hire and fire the people who will do the work, and not to have to be forced to hire people who are not their choice but are the choice of the union. Some of them might not wish to work in an iron lung, if I may use that expression. We will not have any truck with that sort of change. We insist that the change must encompass tackling the monopoly power of the Waterside Workers Federation.

We have no desire to attack any particular union. No particular union is entitled to hold the people of Australia to ransom. We expect the Waterside Workers Federation to attract its membership by being the best union, not conscripting people by having monopoly powers on the waterfront. We say that the argument-I gave it in encapsulated form when quoting the packing and unpacking of containers-that the Waterside Workers Federation should have some monopoly has to go. We believe there has to be genuine enterprise employment, with the power to stand people down and to do all the things that are normal in a contract of employment. We believe that these essential elements of the Inter-State Commission's report deserve the support of the Government and the Opposition because they would bring great benefits to the people of Australia.

We are often challenged in this place to say what we as an Opposition would do to solve Australia's economic problems. Reform of the waterfront is a $600m-plus contribution to solving Australia's economic problems. It is one of the necessary steps which must be taken. On behalf of the Opposition I commend this motion as a matter of genuine urgency, as this country tumbles towards bankruptcy and our people suffer unbelievable hardship under a regime of ridiculously high interest rates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.
