TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —While I am indebted to Senator Chaney for his passing compliment in the course of his speech about my approach to micro-economic reform, which is not calculated to assist me in my next pre-selection, I have to say nonetheless that so far as wasting the time of the Senate goes, in this very same week that a major statement is to come down from the Government addressing all the issues that are the subject matter of this motion, this effort of Senator Chaney's today is in a class of its own. The reform of the waterfront is, and manifestly has been, a major priority in the Hawke Government's micro-economic agenda. We acknowledge it to be a matter of urgency. We do not need any motion of this kind to put it to us in those terms. I will be happy to detail a little later the kind of effort this Government has already undertaken up until now in pursuit of such reform. Later in the week I will be very happy to make a much more detailed statement on behalf of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) as to how we are addressing the issue right now.

SPEECH.PARA: There is only one reason why waterfront reform has become so necessary-we acknowledge it to be such-that is, that the conservative parties, both during the Fraser years and in their preceding decades in government, allowed gross deficiencies to develop in the shipping industries and on the waterfront. Many of the present underlying problems on the waterfront, which we do acknowledge exist, stretch back to the introduction of containerisation in the late 1960s. This was a time when the coalition was in power but it failed to address in any systematic or coherent way the issues that were brought about by such a fundamental change. The Fraser Government's approach to these problems was simply to duck for cover by handing the industry over to the employers and the unions to fix. Fraser abolished the Australian Stevedoring Industry Authority in 1977 and handed over most of its functions to the Association of Employers of Waterfront Labour, the AEWL, which now controls employment arrangements in conjunction with the Waterside Workers Federation (WWF). The then Government did not begin to attempt to put any strategy in place to ensure that improvements were achieved. Its record of micro-economic reform on the waterfront, as elsewhere, was a great big fat zero. That is the basis on which Senator Chaney and his colleagues come and preach the nostrums that we have been hearing today. They have never had any positive ideas about how to address these issues, only destructive ones. I will come in a moment to what the current batch of ideas amount to, as spelt out in the Future Directions documents.

To the extent that one is able to gauge the credentials of the Opposition parties when it comes to a difficult and tricky measure of micro-economic reform in which vested interests are obviously playing a considerable role, one has only to look at the appalling performance in the context of wheat deregulation in recent weeks to see what heart, what stomach, there is on the Opposition side to address these admittedly extremely difficult and hard issues with a long history of entrenched inefficiency and mismanagement behind them. One looks for more than hollow, empty grandstanding rhetoric of the kind we heard today from Senator Chaney and of the kind which is no doubt going to become endemic under the Opposition led by Andrew Peacock. That is the only kind of approach to political problem solving that is understood by this Opposition.

The Future Directions document which Mr Peacock has said will be retained as the Opposition's policy manifesto says that the problems we are experiencing on the waterfront, as elsewhere, have been brought about by `restrictive trade practices which have vested unions with excessive power'. The solution proposed by the coalition in that document is the implementation of essential services legislation. If that is the kind of legislative cooperation that Senator Chaney is offering us today, if that is the hand of friendship he stretches across the chamber, not only in the context of buying out through appropriations to pay for some redundancy, if he is handing us the offer of legislation of that kind, which he has gone on record and has not stepped away from--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am offering you that program.

—Senator Chaney may be offering us that, but he also has behind that velvet glove-it is essentially a velvet gloved program, for all the abuse he has hurled on Mr Willis, Mr Morris and those of us who appreciate the need for a cooperative and cautious approach to this attitude--
—To your knowledge justified-what I had to say about Willis.

—I do not concede that for a moment. What I am saying is that to the extent that there is a softer approach embodied in the Industries Assistance Commission report, to the extent that it does involve some attempt through appropriate financial support to the industry to secure redundancies that might not otherwise be obtainable, then that softer approach is the one the Government has already said in principle it adopts and will be seeking to implement. But it is not that kind of approach which has traditionally lain behind the Opposition's approach to these issues. Whatever Senator Chaney may be saying today-I am interested to have him spell out his stepping away from the Future Directions documents-it is obvious, notwithstanding Mr Peacock's re-statement of the value and centrality of that document to the Opposition's thinking, that there is going to be a steady stepping away from it. If this is the first sign we have seen of it today, so much the better for the future of this country. If we are to take seriously the kind of underlying approach to these policy issues that is writ large in that document, then one must believe that a return to the mailed fist of essential services legislation is very much a centrepiece of what the Opposition has in mind in dealing with this and related issues-that is to say, the politics of confrontation. If we apply the politics of confrontation to the environment that we are all too well aware exists in many of these difficult areas, not least the waterfront and shipping services, what we are talking about is a recipe for massive further damaging disruption. It is that consensual approach, the approach that tries to establish long term sustainable reform through negotiated consensus, the approach that is absolutely central to the thinking and style in government of my colleagues Ralph Willis and Peter Morris, that will ensure genuine longstanding reform in this as in other areas, not the kind of heavy-handed government prescription which is, and certainly has been in the past, central to the Opposition's approach to these issues.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very sad tale, a repeat of apathy and neglect, that the Opposition can offer by way of credentials in dealing with this sort of issue. In all that is ever said by the Opposition on this or any other micro-reform issue, the first question that must be asked in order to test the credibility of the claims and the prescriptions that are being made is: what did the Opposition do when it had the chance over nearly 30 years in government to do something about these industries when problems were showing up? What did it do? Where are the runs on the board? There are no runs on the board, and it is a matter of extreme gall and effrontery that we should be preached to in this fashion by an Opposition that is so conspicuously lacking in any effective performance. The chutzpah in this respect is rivalled only by the futility of seeking to debate this question at a time when my colleague Mr Willis is due later this week to deliver a major statement on reform of coastal shipping and the waterfront. Even Senator Chaney would realise that I am not in a position-I am not about to and do not want to-to pre-empt that statement here today, except to say that what is announced will be the result of exhaustive study and exhaustive discussion between all the parties. It has been an exhaustive process, and I will spell out in a few moments what it involves. I repeat that we have demonstrated across a broad range of micro-economic issues that the way to long term, sustainable reform is through that sort of process of exhaustive study and discussion rather than heavy-handed confrontation of the kind that has become endemic over the years in the Opposition's style when it has been in government and what we can certainly expect from the Future Directions document to be the basic prescription for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you committed to this report? What are you saying?

—I am saying no more than I have said already. I am not about to pre-empt the statement. The Government, through Mr Willis, has expressed a general commitment to the basic themes, the basic directions, the basic flavour, shape and direction of that document. The detailed response to that report and to this issue will be on the table later this week and I do not seek to pre-empt it.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the underlying themes of Senator Chaney's speech, and indeed every other contribution by the Opposition on this question, has been the alleged willingness of the Government to run away from an effective commitment to micro-economic reform. I think that it is about time that the position was yet again stated clearly, specifically, un- equivocally and accurately for the record. This Government has already been one of the great achievers in micro-economic reform, structural adjustment and everything that goes with it.

Let me list for the record what the dimensions of that reform have been, because waterfront and shipping as well will form very much a part of this list by the time that the Minister's statement is made at the end of this week. Let me begin with the most fundamental area, which is tariff reform. We have had motor vehicle tariff reform involving the removal of tariff quotas on motor vehicles and the reduction of tariffs from 57 1/2 per cent to 35 per cent by January 1992. We have had textiles, clothing and footwear protection reform, with quotas being phased out by 1995, to leave then tariff-only protection. We have had general tariff reform. Quite apart from the two industries I have just mentioned and a small number of rates that would otherwise have become anomalous, all tariffs above 15 per cent are being reduced to 15 per cent, and those tariffs between 10 per cent and 15 per cent are being reduced to 10 per cent, all over four years to July 1992. The overall effect is a 30 per cent tariff reduction. The general revenue duty of 2 per cent was abolished at a cost of $240m, again grasping a nettle which had been conspicuously rejected over and over again by preceding governments when they had the opportunity to deal with this and all those other matters.

In May 1988 a systematic set of agricultural reforms was announced. Assistance to sugar, dried vine fruit, tobacco and citrus industries was converted to tariff and subject to the same reductions as applied to manufacturing industry. Generally domestic administered price arrangements have been liberalised, and there has been removal of the fertiliser subsidy. They were all hard, tough decisions to take, but those decisions have been taken, as decisions in respect of the waterfront in relation to shipping will be taken, with the best interests of this nation in mind.

In the area of aviation we have had the termination of the two-airline agreement announced, allowing greater competition and lower air fares to take effect in October 1990. We have had liberalisation of international passenger charter policy announced at the same time, and liberalisation of air freight in a variety of specific ways which will be the subject of further announcements shortly. We have had other transport reforms, with improvement in performance in the rail freight network, including grain handling. This has been addressed by our recent announcement that we will have the stomach to introduce, whatever the reaction may finally prove to be in from the Opposition, measures to override restrictive State grain transport regulations, particularly those establishing rail monopolies.

In the area of oil and gas marketing, we have had enormously significant deregulation of the crude oil industry effective from 1 January 1988. Refiners and crude oil producers have had the capacity to negotiate freely the quantities and prices of crude oil they buy and sell. There has been the termination of the administered natural gas pricing formula, allowing at the same time a more flexible approach to price setting and relegating export controls to a strictly reserve power. Again, that has been micro-reform of a fundamentally significant kind. There has been ample opportunity going back for decades for the Opposition to do something about it, but there was never anything more than the kind of hollow, empty rhetoric such as we have heard today.

The telecommunications micro-reform package that I announced in May 1988 allows effective competition in the provision of customer premises equipment in relation to value added services and other telecommunications services, such as phone maintenance and so on, through regulatory changes, and also through the establishment to take effect from July this year of Austel as an independent body to subsume Telecom's regulatory functions, thus allowing effective competition in that area as well. All of this has been accompanied by an information industries plan, announced by the Government in 1987, to encourage multinational computer companies to increase their research and development and manufacturing operations in Australia.

In addition to all that, there has been reform generally of government business enterprises. Over 40 longstanding controls have been removed from nearly all the enterprises, not just in the transport, aviation and communications sectors but across the board, including their right to enter into contracts without ministerial approval, exemption from processes under the Public Works Committee Act, the ability to invest surplus moneys and enter into loan contracts, rights to hire and fire chief executives, the removal of many Public Service staffing and administrative practices, and the right to establish their own superannuation schemes. Those are either in place or have been announced. They are fundamental changes of a kind which previous governments comprising Liberal-National Party Ministers have never had the heart or the stomach to introduce, although they had ample reservoirs of the kind of rhetoric we have heard today.

The whole question of industry regulation was the subject of a major announcement in December 1988 introducing a request and response procedure for review of existing regulations and providing for industry driven regulatory reform. I shall not stop to mention, in addition to all of that, the tax reform measures, the reduction in company rates-again talked about for years, but matters which those opposite never did anything about when they had the chance to do so. There has been the rationalisation of a range of distorting tax reductions, and finally the liberalisation and deregulation of the entire financial system-just to cap off a record which on any view, by any account, by any criteria, is stunning. It is a reform which was long overdue to be implemented by a government because of the course of neglect over decades by those opposite when they had ample chance to do something about the position.

The course of waterfront reform has been protracted; it has been difficult and drawn out. It goes back to July 1984 when we sponsored the shore based shipping costs seminar. It extended from there to September 1984 when the industry task force on shore based shipping costs was established under the chairmanship of Mr Ian Webber. In response to those reports a further group of major studies and initiatives were put together, involving finally in December 1986 the formulation of an across-the-board waterfront strategy involving four separate dimensions. I refer to the Stevedoring Industry Review Committee examining employment related issues in the stevedoring sector; the Industry Committee reviewing impediments arising from commercial practices, inadequate documentation and communication systems; the importer-exporter panel representing the client industries on the waterfront; and the marine and ports group and the railway group of the Australian Transport Advisory Council progressing initiatives to address rail and port authority issues in consultation or with the involvement of the State and Territory governments. They are four hugely important, interrelated dimensions demonstrating by their very nature the complexity of the task.

While all that was happening the Inter-State Commission was tasked to prepare its report bringing those various threads together. That process has been going on for some time now, until the publication in April this year of the Inter-State Commission's final report. The recommendations of the Inter-State Commission, as Senator Chaney said, and as I cheerfully acknowledged, are aimed at addressing all aspects of the waterfront industry with a focus on fundamental structural change in the stevedoring sector. Those recommendations involve a major shift from current industry-wide employment arrangements to enterprise based employment. They involve in the container depot sector the elimination of a number of existing industrial constraints on international container depot operations. They do involve in the port authorities, a review by State and Territory governments of the allocation of port functions with a proposal that many commercial functions be divested and performed by differently structured authorities. These recommendations also involve the view that the Trade Practices Commission should develop greater expertise and generally take a more active role in this area.

All of these recommendations are important. They do have a prima facie attractiveness about them and that has been acknowledged as such by the Government. But, as far as possible, we have been seeking to get consensus and negotiated solutions to the problems in this area because we know from hard-won experience that the kicking heads approach, the legislative override approach, the insensitive approach, is not the one that produces sustainable long term reform, and it is sustainable long term reform that is needed on the waterfront. While the unions and the stevedoring employers have indicated reservations, as Senator Chaney has said and as I acknowledge, about certain aspects of the report, it is the case that both groups have confirmed their acceptance of the need for waterfront reform and their general acceptance of the shape and direction of the proposals that are contained in the ISC report. The Hawke Government acknowledges a responsibility to take the lead to address the need for greater efficiency on the waterfront. The will for change exists, and the results of this combined effort and the way forward will be made clear in the Government's very detailed statement, later this week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on this matter of urgency is a re-run of the debate on 10 April when virtually the same urgency motion was proposed. On that occasion, the Australian Democrats supported the urgency motion.
—It is even more urgent now.

—Perhaps it is a little more urgent now. Nevertheless, it is a re-run of precisely the same proposition that we debated in this chamber on 10 April. On 10 April the proposition was that the reform of the waterfront was to ensure efficiency and productivity rather than a national burden and an impediment. It would have been very difficult to disagree with that proposition, in the same way as today, in many respects, it is difficult to disagree with the proposition that we have before us, which suggests, as a matter of urgency, that the Government needs to ensure a flexible and efficient working environment on the Australian waterfront. Of course it does. The motion says that it should achieve this through lasting and genuine reforms. Of course it should. However, it is a question of how one achieves those genuine and lasting reforms. I must admit that the Australian Democrats have some reservations about whether those genuine and lasting reforms will be achieved by an aggressive, confrontationist approach in an industrial environment which has a history which suggests that confrontation and aggression are potentially disastrous.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not arguing with the essential elements of the proposition of the need for reform. I do not think anybody in his or her right mind would question the need for reform on the waterfront, nor does anybody challenge the essential validity and value of the report of the Inter-State Commission entitled Waterfront Investigation, known as the Butcher report. As Senator Chaney emphasised in his words of introduction, it is a most comprehensive, a most timely and a most responsible report, and the fundamental plan which is inherent in it is rational and attractive. It has been admitted as being attractive to the Government. In the final analysis all these things are a question of degree and of method.

In listening to Senator Chaney's remarks today-we acknowledge the fact that this re-run of the debate of 10 April is due to the fact that Senator Chaney is now the shadow Minister for industrial relations-I sensed that there was an element of image building inherent in the propositions that were advanced in such a forthright manner. When the shadow portfolio recently changed, some commentators observed the fact that Senator Chaney might be seen to be softer in his approach to his portfolio than was his predecessor. That is probably a valid observation. One senses that here today there has been some image building, some toughening, some hardening of the stomach, some flexing of the tough abdominal muscles of our new shadow Minister for industrial relations. I sense that because we have the same proposition before us today, after the change of portfolios, as we had before us on 10 April. In some respects Senator Chaney is projecting his new tough image in relation to industrial relations. To proffer an aggressive line in one of the toughest industrial arenas would have been an opportunity that he would have found too difficult to pass over.

Nevertheless, the Australian Democrats support the proposition that there is need for reform on the waterfront. We acknowledge the centrality and criticality of the waterfront to remedying our balance of payments difficulties. We see it as being central to a healthy economy and we endorse and support the fundamental recommendations and plans that have been advanced by the Inter-State Commission. I suppose we differ from Senator Chaney over the adoption of an aggressive and confrontationist approach to one controversial element-that of introducing competition to the waterfront. It is in that respect that we have serious reservations. In replying to Senator Chaney, Senator Gareth Evans said that if we were to achieve successful transformation of the Australian waterfront it would come about as a result of a cooperative and cautious approach rather than as a result of a confrontationist approach. Essentially, the Democrats agree with that and, for that reason, we will not be supporting the proposition put forward by the Opposition. It is not that we do not see it as a matter of urgency or importance, but that we differ as to the method and strategy. We observed in Senator Chaney's statement to the Senate today that he is giving a warning that as far as an alternative government is concerned it would be a boots and all approach to the waterfront. Frankly, we see that as being potentially disastrous.

It is absolutely vital that one is cognisant of the history of the Australian waterfront when we move to implement a plan to remedy its inadequacies. It has been a battleground of the labour forces over the years, and the attitudes that have prevailed in that battleground will not be cast aside very readily. The apportionment of blame is always difficult. There has been a tendency, because of the bad image of the waterfront, to point the finger of blame only at labour. Such action ignores the fact that in any industrial context management has to accept its portion of the blame. So if the climate has been difficult and the waterfront has been a battleground, we do not believe that that blame lies wholly and solely with labour. In fact, this has been acknowledged in some of the comments that have come from those who have written in the press and made contributions and statements to the Commission prior to its bringing down its excellent report.

I refer to some of the reactions to the Butcher report. I believe that the reactions have been quite encouraging. Writing in the Australian Financial Review of 10 November 1988, Anne Davies states that the Waterside Workers Federation (WWF) has given a clear signal that it is prepared to negotiate on significant changes to employment arrangements and will even consider a move to company employment. She goes on to say:
The proposals were included in the WWF submission to the Inter-State Commission, which is devising a strategy to improve efficiency on the waterfront.

Regarded as one of the most intractable unions in the country, the WWF indicated in its submission that it was prepared to discuss significant change in the industry, even on issues that were previously off the agenda, such as company employment.
I am not pessimistic about the signs and reactions that have been forthcoming from the Butcher report. An article that appeared in the Australian on 30 June states:
MSB-
that is, the Maritime Services Board-
general manager, Mr Les MacDonald told the commission during its Sydney hearings recently that various groups on the waterfront appeared to be trying to lay the blame for problems on others.
In the article Mr Les MacDonald says:

We all have contributions to make to the solution of the problems that exist on the waterfront and in the transport chain. It is important for all of us to accept at least part of the blame for the problems.
The article continues:
He said the commission should look at how many of the links in the transport chain were really necessary.

One of the main contributors to the cost levels in the transportation of goods from the farm or mine to the ship, and transportation of goods inwards, was the amount of players in the chain in Australia, he said.
In other words, Mr MacDonald was urging us to accept our share of the responsibility in tidying up the problems of the historically very vexed Australian waterfront.

The Commission cites some of the fundamental structural problems. It cites the fact that the work force is an ageing work force. It is one within which there are likely to be considerable difficulties in accepting the sorts of massive innovations that are necessary for the transitions to occur. It cites the fact that in work methods, and particularly in recording and processing of information and communication, there are duplications and delays and the methods are antiquated. Even those who lead the union movement on the waterfront cite these as sources of great difficulty. An article by Michelle Grattan in the Age of 24 April 1989 quotes Tas Bull, the leader of the WWF, on the structure of his work force:

`It looks like Dad's army-of course it does', admits the WWF's general secretary Tas Bull . . . `Thirty-three per cent of our members are over 55. There has been no recruitment in Sydney or Melbourne since 1975; no recruitment in Adelaide for 22 years, and only 10 recruited in Hobart since 1956.'

We have a work force that is entrenched in its attitudes and in its methods. It is inherently inflexible. It is a difficult industrial climate to work in. With the implementation of the excellent recommendations or fundamentals of the Butcher plan, there will have to be-as Senator Evans has emphasised-a strategy which is essentially one of cooperation and caution.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't have time.

—Senator Parer suggests we do not have time. We have to make time. If we create and return to the industrial turmoil and chaos of the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s in this arena, we will achieve nothing. We are confronted with an extraordinarily difficult and challenging economic climate. It is true that the clean-up and the improvement of the waterfront are fundamental to the improvement of the economy. But the confrontationist approach to industrial relations on that traditional, historical battleground of industrial relations is fraught with disaster.

SPEECH.PARA: The plea of the Australian Democrats, as we move towards the implementation of the Butcher plan, is by all means to acknowledge the difficulties but to proceed with caution, to be rational and deliberate, and to accept the fact that the patterns of the waterfront in the past reflect the attitudes not only of labour but also of management. If we are to resolve these problems, it will have to be with an approach different from the one inherent in the proposition before the chamber today. It will have to be an approach different from the one outlined by Senator Chaney in his opening remarks in this debate. In essence, Senator Chaney said that the Opposition will support the Government in the implementation of the Butcher plan and that it is a good plan. However, he said that that will happen only provided the most controversial and confrontationist element of the plan-namely, the deregulation of labour and the heightening of competition-is addressed immediately and aggressively. Fundamentally, that is a contradictory statement. The successful implementation of this plan will depend upon caution and cooperation. I believe that Senator Chaney, in this urgency motion, is proposing not caution and cooperation but rather confrontation and aggression. For that reason the Australian Democrats oppose the urgency motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the urgency motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to ensure a flexible and efficient working environment on the Australian waterfront through lasting and genuine reforms, including the introduction of full enterprise employment, appropriate changes in union coverage and the elimination of restrictive work practices.

The fact that such an urgency motion has to be brought on for debate is evidenced by the recent media reports that the Federal Government and the waterfront unions are deadlocked in discussions over reforms. I make some points about another agreement that the parties have tried to put together just recently. On a one-off retirement and redundancy package, a position paper prepared by the parties states:
There is no agreement in respect of early retirement arrangements for new entrants and further discussions will be necessary.
On recruitment it states:
This aspect is not agreed at this time by the unions.
On enterprise employment it states:
However there are fundamental matters which are not agreed and which will require further detailed discussion and resolution in relation to enterprise employment.
On award and job restructuring it states:
Agreement has not been reached an all matters.
On stand-down provisions it states:
The Parties to date have been unable to reach agreement on this matter.
On contract maintenance it states:
The Parties to date have been unable to reach agreement on this matter.
On container depots it states:
The Parties to date have been unable to reach agreement on this matter.
On loading and discharging bulk vessels it states:
The Unions are not prepared to withdraw from membership coverage . . .

It goes on. As Senator Parer has already interjected in this debate, this is urgent; this has to be attended to. For the good of Australia this has to be confronted and something has to be done about it.

The trouble is that the Federal Government-and especially the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)-foolishly believes it is in control of Government policy. That is where this Labor Government is wrong. It has already been proved wrong many times in the last few years. The Government depends on the unions for its retention of government but forgets that the cost of this dependence is control by the unions over government policy. That is no secret. The unions have always made their power well and truly known to the Australian Labor Party.

The simple truth is that the Government is in a real mess over reforms on the waterfront. It made an undertaking to the Opposition during the wheat legislation debate that if the wheat growers made similar concessions it would move towards reform on the waterfront. If the Wheat Marketing Bill were to be passed, the Australian wheat growers would give up an orderly market system and be exposed to operations on a deregulated market. If that happens, it will be the Government's turn to honour its end of the bargain with its constituency. But here is the crunch: it cannot deliver because the unions will not deliver. The unions will not let the Government do it. I can give the assurance that this side of the chamber will be pursuing deregulation on the waterfront to the end, and right to the edge of the water.

All the talk about major policy announcements on reforms can be seen to be hot air. We read headlines that talks are bogged down and deadlocked over matters such as the size of the golden handshake needed to get rid of the deadwood on the wharves. Anybody who does not believe that there is deadwood needs only to read the rort report prepared by Senator Parer's office recently. It is so unbelievable that it could almost be a fairytale. For Australian farmers it is no fairytale. They know only too well the rorts and rip-offs on the wharves. Their whole year's work is often left sitting at risk of perishing or losing the market, because of the whims and fancies of the waterside workers.

An illustration of that was given last night on 60 Minutes. It was a program about a waterside worker spending some time on a farm and a farmer spending some time on the waterfront. The farmer's first comment when he was in front of the television cameras on the waterfront, when anyone could have staged it if he had wanted to, was, `How many old people are here on the waterfront'. He also said, `Look at all those people over there who are not doing anything'. He was asked some other questions and his words, which I think were interesting, were, `It was pretty boring because there wasn't much for me to do on the waterfront.'

The waterfront worker who went to the farm to do some work-a nice person and probably the youngest person, apart from the farmer, whom we saw on the television interview-made the point about how hard the work on the farm was. Another comment he made was that when something went wrong on the farm the farmer fixed it up and got on with the job whereas, on the waterfront, when two bolts were missing from a crane at one stage, everyone stopped work. The cost of that to the Australian export industry and to the Australian person is too high for this country to continue to pay in the future.

We must not under-estimate the importance of an efficient waterfront to Australian trade, particularly the agricultural trade. Again, that is the point of Senator Parer's earlier interjection when he said that we must get on and do the job. The vast majority of Australia's overseas trade goes through the waterfront. In fact, the report of the Industries Assistance Commission on coastal shipping, published last July, claimed that over 99 per cent passes through Australian ports. Each day, $50m-worth of exports and $76m-worth of imports need to pass across the Australian waterfront. Since many of the same ports are involved in both domestic and international trade, the cost of inefficiency affects nearly every other industry in the economy. Australia's trade is exceptionally vulnerable to many unnecessary costs and unreliability. It is this vulnerability that has given waterfront employees the ability to negotiate conditions of employment that are generally well in excess of community standards and has permitted the absolute proliferation of work practices that today are commonly referred to as rorts.

Let me give the Senate a few examples. A national amenities agreement exists whereby an amenities man is provided on the waterfront whenever 15 A-registered workers are employed. His job is to wipe down tables in the amenities rooms after breaks. He may also act in a security capacity to look after workers' personal belongings. I can understand the last requirement as theft and pilferage are rife on the wharves. The amenities job goes on day and night; so, if 15 A-registered workers are rostered on during a day, an amenities man must be provided for the day shift and another on the night shift regardless of the number of workers actually working. This man's job is not to clean up; other cleaners are provided to do that. He is there to act as a butler to waterside workers. In Brisbane alone the annual bill for the wages of the amenities men was some $365,000, on-cost not included.

There is a rort involving glutmen on Brisbane wharves. Currently, two glutmen must be employed when preglutted timber packs are being worked on the wharves. Their alleged purpose is to pick up any gluts which may fall off the timber packs. The incidence of gluts falling off, I am told, is rare and certainly does not necessitate the employment of two workers permanently allocated to this function just waiting for things to fall off. Then there are the nick-off days when members of a gang draw straws to see who can return home for the day on full pay.

At Newcastle port there are 54 foremen and supervisors for 186 waterside workers. There seems a fair bit of chiefdom and not many Indians. At Wyndham in Western Australia, the 30 waterside workers average eight hours of work per week. Overmanning is rife among the tug operators. As with coastal ships there is a second crew for each tug, even though tugs do not leave their port. Currently at Melbourne full separate receival and full separate delivery gangs must be employed per vessel regardless of the workload involved. If 10 boxes were to be unloaded and 10 boxes were to be delivered to a vessel, two separate gangs would have to be employed. The Inter-State Commission report lists the average Australian efficient overseas container handling rate for 1988, and I seek leave to table the chart.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The chart sets out quite clearly how inefficient Australian ports are. Crane efficiency is an indicator of how well working time is being used, and the chart shows that Australian crane operations are about half as efficient as the average overseas crane operations. The International Cargo Handling Coordination Association provided information to the Inter-State Commission which cited that Australia's major container ports are half as productive as their European counterparts and 40 per cent as productive as many Asian ports. Australian ports were the least efficient of all the ports surveyed.

SPEECH.PARA: I quote another recent study conducted by staff of the Industries Assistance Commission which found that 20 per cent improvement in labour productivity in the water transport industry combined with faster turnaround time of ships in ports would produce an initial cost saving of $860m in 1986-87 money terms. Senator Chaney has already mentioned that point. The report goes on to say:
This would lead in the long run to an increase of $1.1 billion in GDP.

That is a large amount of money. The effect of the rorts and torts and the efficiencies on the waterfront can be brought to the attention of the Senate by referring to a letter that a Tamworth company, Bettington Commodities, wrote to me about the problems associated with the waterfront:

My business is a small, totally Australian-based trading and packing business-my office is located in Tamworth (New South Wales) and the packing business, (established totally to develop export business), in Brisbane.

I commenced my current business three and a half years ago as a domestic grain trader and was able to quickly establish myself in the industry. Last year, 1987, I began to show interest in starting to develop some export markets. I was successful in securing a contract to supply 2,000 tonnes of cotton seed to a client in Saudi Arabia . . . The customer was so pleased with the product and the way it was packed, that I managed to sell (to the same customer), a further 5,000 tonnes of cotton seed for delivery from June to August 1988. I was also able to sell to another client in Saudi Arabia a further 1500 tonnes of cotton seed for shipment in May 1988. The gross value of this business was approximately $2.2Million . . .
That is good export income for Australia. The letter continued:

At the same time I also managed to secure other new overseas business, principally to Japan, for cotton seed. The business amounted to a further 11,000 tonnes or approximately $2.9Million of business. Therefore, I managed to secure over $5Million worth of new export business for Australia . . . However, all has not been so pleasing.

We successfully packed our first 1500 tonnes of product to be shipped to Saudi Arabia in our one-tonne bags using unique equipment that I had specially manufactured for the purpose. We were booked to ship this consignment on a Yugoslavian ship belonging to J.S.P. Lines, called the `Heroj Paic'. The ship arrived in Brisbane Port on 25 May, 1988 and was to unload containers at Fisherman's Island Container Terminal. This was not commenced until 26 May, due to congestion at the terminal, but when the ship did in fact begin to unload, the rate of unloading was at less than five containers per hour. I am told that at any port in the world on that ship, fifteen containers per hour would be a normal slow rate and in good ports up to forty-five containers is possible.

Eventually the ship was loaded by the following Monday . . . some fourteen days after arriving at port for what should have been three to four days work. Due to the delays mentioned, we have become liable to pay demurrage to the shipping line of USD$3,000.00 per day . . .
My budgeted cost was a maximum of $28.00 per tonne . . .

All I can say, without continuing to read this letter, is that this person, who was going to supply an export income for the people of Australia, was thwarted in that attempt by a waterfront that had callous disregard for his income or the income that Australia would receive. This gentleman has had to close that export facility and Australia is the poorer for it. I support the motion moved this afternoon by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. The Government must take heed of it and get on with the job of reforming the waterfront. If other people have to pay their share they will do so, but our exports leave from the waterfront--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with an Opposition urgency motion in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to ensure a flexible and efficient working environment on the Australian waterfront through lasting and genuine reforms, including the introduction of full enterprise employment, appropriate changes in union coverage and the elimination of restrictive work practices.

The Government accepts the need for lasting and genuine reform on the waterfront. We have taken the initiative on this matter. As Senator Gareth Evans pointed out, after two years of work the Inter-State Commission report is before Cabinet right now. At this moment Cabinet is considering the recommendations of the report and other matters. The Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) is due to make a statement at the end of this week. Mr Willis has had extensive discussions with the parties in the waterfront industry. One might well ask-and we ask today-why the Opposition decides that there is some urgency about this matter when it knows very well that next week it can discuss the Government's reaction to the report.

We are very concerned as to why the Opposition does things in this way. On 10 April, the last time we had a debate on this matter, the Waterside Workers Federation (WWF) Council met to consider its reaction to the report. In other words, it had had the report for a few days and was considering it as a national body. Incidentally, I note that nine days after it had the report it gave its initial response to the Government. On 10 April the Opposition moved an urgency motion, and on that occasion the same sorts of things occurred as have occurred today. We had inflammatory attacks on workers and unions in the waterfront industry, and this has been repeated today by Senator Chaney.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been attacking the Hawke Government. Don't worry about the workers. Let's get on to the Hawke Government and what it is not doing.

—The attitude of the Opposition is reflected by the constant interjections of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. He has been following the lead of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney. The Opposition wishes to change the world to an ideological framework that fits in with its preconceived ideas. It has great difficulty in dealing with the real world and, more particularly, with how it will change human beings in an industry so that people will have, in the words of the Opposition's motion, `lasting and genuine reforms'. That is what we are about. We know enough about this matter to know that if one intends to change people in an industry-and that means both the employers and the employees-one must have a process of cooperation. One must have agreed goals in order to change the situation that, in many cases, has existed over many years. In the case of the waterfront there have been many bitter years, which have left a residue of hatred and all sorts of lead in the saddlebags as far as reform is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Having regard to that background, this Government is now moving to achieve change. We are seeking a solution. Mr Willis, the appropriate Minister, has met separately with employers, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and other people involved. He met separately with them on 14 April and on 28 April. There has been a continual process of discussion to this point. Senator Chaney finds this very offensive. When he opened the debate for the Opposition he talked about the Minister being locked away with unions and employers. What a terrible thing it is for the Minister now to start talking with employers and unions to get them finally to agree to various proposals! That process has been accelerated and there has been a great deal of agreement in principle on the major matters facing the industry.

Why does Senator Chaney, when he leads for the Opposition, talk about `stomachs'? He gratuitously insulted Senator Gareth Evans and, in turn, other Ministers, by saying that they did not have the stomach to do certain things. This is the macho talk of the Opposition. This is the sort of `stand and deliver' type of attitude of political ideologues that certainly has no place in industry policy. It was worrying to see in yesterday's Sunday Telegraph that Mr Copeman, the endorsed New Right candidate for the Phillip electorate, praised Senator Chaney. It is almost as though Senator Chaney is changing his political position to become more macho and have the stomach to fight all and sundry in an ideological way, without being concerned about the actual needs of the waterfront industry.

When one considers the matters that have been referred to in the motion, one sees that full enterprise employment is mentioned. What is significant is that the Waterside Workers Federation has accepted in principle the question of industry employment. Industry-wide employment arrangements have existed in the stevedoring industry for several decades-and for good reason, as it ensures maximum flexibility and availability of labour in an industry which experiences dramatic daily fluctuations in its labour requirements.

The Inter-State Commission proposed that the fluctuations be resolved by supplementary labour, which has been discussed between the parties and is a matter of controversy. I believe that the real hurdle to agreement was the proposal that the WWF relinquish its union coverage. This was a curious proposal, in my view. It is one that everybody seems to be concerned about. I have been informed that not one of the 280 submissions presented to the Inter-State Commission contains that proposal. It is no wonder that the ACTU, the State trades and labour councils and the Western Australian and Victorian governments support the Waterside Workers Federation's opposition to that proposal. I will not be surprised if the Government does not accept that recommendation. I would not believe for a moment that any government would accept all recommendations by a committee. I have looked carefully at the Opposition's motion. It refers to:
. . . appropriate changes in union coverage . . .

A practical interpretation of `appropriate' would certainly make it acceptable to the trade union movement because nothing else would work. Secondly, I can see that, with amalgamations taking place throughout industry in the next three years, certain changes on the waterfront would be appropriate. I do not have any great problem with that. However, many members of the Opposition see it differently. They see change as an opportunity to destroy trade unionism on the waterfront. That, of course, would not be appropriate. It would be unacceptable, and it is not going to occur.

The Waterside Workers Federation and other unions have declared that they are prepared to negotiate a whole range of changes. Many things that, traditionally, have been difficult to achieve are going to be achieved. Tas Bull, referring in an article to rejuvenation of the industry, retraining and the extension of classifications having enabled the Federation to maintain the labour force at operational strength, lists the following as being necessary:
A training package designed to accommodate new recruits, support a career structure and provide increased skill acquisition and job flexibility.
Reclassification of jobs consistent with career structure.
Establishment of an industry training facility.
Company based productivity incentive schemes.
Enforcement of the safety code in law.

These are some of the practical proposals that are very important for the establishment of an efficient industry. They have been agreed in principle by a wide cross-section of organisations: the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour, the Port Waratah Stevedoring Company Pty Ltd, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia, the Australian Stevedoring Supervisors Association, the Australian Foreman Stevedores Association, the Federated Miscellaneous Workers Union, the Federated Clerks Union, the National Union of Workers, the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union and the Electrical Trades Union. That cross-section of people have come together and, in a spirit of cooperation, worked through the principles which, I hope, will apply to the waterfront in the future. No attempt by the Opposition can destroy this new commitment of people in the waterfront industry to modernise. Of course, we welcome that. There is no question but that the state of the waterfront is holding back the expansion of Australian industry. The work that the Government and the industry have done to attempt to change the practices and the organisation of work on the waterfront have been timely.

I think that the Opposition is under a general impression that it should be attacking people in industry. I suspect-though I hesitate to say it-that today Senator Chaney was almost repudiating Future Directions when he was challenged by Senator Evans. He is ambivalent even about the hidden agenda of Future Directions for the waterfront industry, which is use of essential services legislation. The program of the Opposition includes the introduction of essential services legislation. I hope that everyone listening to this debate will realise that that is a prescription for the destruction of all of this country's imports and exports. Essential services legislation means, implicitly, a confrontation on the waterfront and the strangulation of our exports and imports. That is the Opposition's manifesto in Future Directions, yet today Senator Chaney appeared to be relying on the Inter-State Commission's report. He is not quite prepared to acknowledge the essential services legislation proposal, which is the cornerstone of the Opposition's program for the future.

That, of course, fits in with the Opposition's way of doing things-giving orders and standing over people. As Senator Evans said, the way to long-term, sustainable reform is by negotiated consensus, not by heavy-handed Government prescription. I should add that, in this case, neither is it by Opposition prescription, because the parties opposite will never get into Government and, thus, have the opportunity to implement those heavyhanded proposals. Every package of changes that the Government has implemented in respect of industry has been implemented by a process of consultation.

There are no short cuts if one wants a genuine change of attitudes and creation of the initiative that the Opposition has talked about. We have the runs on the board; the Opposition does not. Senator Evans read out a list of the many industries that have had the benefit of qualitative changes in their activities because of the cooperative approach that this Government has adopted. The Opposition would do the opposite if it were ever to gain office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the current and prospective economic climate, this urgency motion is of critical importance to the future of our nation. It covers the waterfront areas that need to be reformed. It refers to:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to ensure a flexible and efficient working environment on the waterfront through lasting and genuine reforms . . .

I was a bit surprised at the remarks of Senator Gareth Evans in his response to Senator Chaney. He kicked off by saying that reform of the waterfront was a major priority of the Hawke Government. However, he went on to say that, notwithstanding the report of the Inter-State Commission (ISC), cooperation and caution were needed. That gives me a feeling of apprehension. Following the report of the Inter-State Commission, it was reported that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself has signalled a reprieve for the Waterside Workers Federation (WWF), which was said to be facing oblivion through sweeping proposals aimed at waterfront reform. The Prime Minister said:
I believe it is going to be possible to achieve through negotiation some significant reforms in a way which will not meet the understandable opposition of the Waterside Workers Federation.

No wonder we are apprehensive. Several senators have asked why such an urgency motion has been introduced at this time, as the Minister is scheduled to bring out a report on Wednesday. The answer is that we in Australia have on our hands an economic disaster, brought about by this Government. What we want to do is introduce a bit of spine into the Government so that something may be done. This country is an island continent. Trade, particularly exports, is vital to the prosperity of every Australian. The thrust of the motion is to encourage the Government to grasp the nettle and reform the waterfront, which, of course, is the Achilles heel of our export trade potential, so that unit costs may be reduced and, of equal or greater importance, so that we may restore our world reputation-a reputation that we have not had for many years-of reliability in the loading and unloading of goods. Our economy is in a parlous state, but the Government has a window of opportunity. It must act with urgency to effect a genuine and lasting substantial improvement in productivity, efficiency and reliability. Unit costs do not consist just of the hourly rate paid to those who work on the wharves, although those are not insignificant. I give a few examples of hourly rates to the Senate. The gross wage for a waterfront worker in the port of Brisbane working 41.3 hours a week is $998 a week. If that is extrapolated for 52 weeks, it is $52,000 a year. A foreman working 41 hours earns $63,336 per annum; a tradesman working 52 hours earns $66,716 per annum; and a supervisor working 47 hours receives $96,200 per annum. I do not want to detract from the thrust of this urgency motion by zeroing in on wages. As I have said many times in this place, I would be happy to accept those wages if we could get rid of the other things associated with the malpractice, the featherbedding and so on, on the waterfront.

The speed and efficiency at which incoming vessels can be berthed, unloaded, loaded and dispatched to their destination is of paramount importance. Archaic work practices and phoney safety issues which cause delays for political reasons must be buried. In the past in this place I have given a list of those sorts of things; I do not think I have to go through them again. There is a litany of these sorts of things. My colleagues Senator Brownhill and Senator Chaney mentioned a few of them. These anti-Australian activities-and I mean anti-Australian activities-not only enhance our unenviable reputation as an unrealiable supplier but also in themselves are the major contributor to unit costs which end up being paid for by Australian exporters or Australian consumers. They are the people who pay. Because of these contrived delays-no-one at all would object to proper safety issues-it is not unusual, for instance, for manufactured goods destined for export not to be loaded and for the ship to leave without its cargo. Sometimes imported capital equipment for our manufacturing industry, which is not unloaded because of time constraints and ongoing demurrage charges further down the shipping line, ends up in a place such as Singapore and eventually finds its way back to Australia. Any shipping agent will tell the same stories; those practices are going on today.

These sorts of practices are totally inexcusable and unacceptable under any circumstances and reflect the mess on our waterfront. There is a group in London called the strike club. Most shippers contribute money into the strike club. Australia's lack of reliability is graphically illustrated by the annual strike club figures compiled by the Shipowners Mutual Strike Insurance Association of London. The strike club measures the percentage of claims for losses incurred by strikes in various countries throughout the world. Australia topped the strike club charts from 1982 to 1987, accounting for a whopping 42.73 per cent of all strike insurance claims received by the Association. Canada ranked a distant second with 19.5 per cent of the claims for the same period. What a reputation we have! As I mentioned earlier, the political reasons for the disputes are phoney. If one looks at the monthly figures, one finds that 80 per cent to 90 per cent of the strikes in the Port of Sydney are because the unions involved do not like the policies of the South African Government. What has that got to do with the shipping of goods in and out of the port?

The Inter-State Commission has carried out an extensive and, as Senator Chaney said, apolitical study. Its recommendations must be implemented in full if we are to clean up the mess. There can be no watering down. For the sake of Australia, the Government must take this on board. Partial implementation will be an absolute failure at, yet again, great expense to the taxpayer. We agree that subsidies should be given for the redundancies of people who should retire, but that will be at great cost to all Australians. These are the hidden costs. When the air traffic controllers go on strike we know about it because so many people are affected. But ordinary people do not see the hidden costs to them individually of the waterfront practices.

As Senator Chaney said, the Opposition has stated that it will give bipartisan support to the Government if it has the character and intestinal fortitude to implement the recommendations of the ISC in full as a matter of urgency. The economic position of Australia is so desperate in this country that for the Government not to do so would be an act of treachery to the nation. We are not alone in talking about the desperate economic situation in Australia. Last Friday Senator Button said in this chamber in answer to a question.
The Australian economy is in a very serious position.

Honourable senators on the other side were running around the place saying, `How are we going to stop the press from picking it up?'. But Senator Button recognised what the rest of Australia recognises. Our concern is that the Government will not take action. All the signs are there. They have come out in remarks made by Senator Evans and Senator Childs. Anyone with any knowledge of the industry will be aware of the intense nature of the negotiations over the past two weeks between employers and employees with both the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Willis, and senior officers of his Department. Everyone with any idea of the industry is also aware of the veiled and not so veiled threats by the Government for employers to capitulate to union intransigency in critical areas which, if agreed, would gut the ISC recommendations. Those areas are labour pooling, casual employment in peak periods-in other words, allowing stevedores to employ casual labour in peak periods-union coverage in small ports and container depots, and the contracting out of maintenance work. There are now newspaper reports that these intense negotiations were not negotiations at all but consultations. That is the terminology. Anyone with a smattering of knowledge of the industry-I am sure that Senator Childs is aware of it-knows how intense they were, but they are now `consultations'. Notwithstanding initial adverse comments made by Mr Kelty of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and Mr Bull of the Waterside Workers Federation and a statement made last week by Mr John Coombs, assistant secretary of the WWF, that they would `never budge' from the critical areas I have just mentioned, we are still expected to believe that a meaningful statement will be made next Wednesday. How can we believe that after the comments made by both Senator Evans and Senator Childs that have been leaked to the newspapers?

The economic situation in Australia is so serious and desperate that we cannot afford any further delays. If there are further delays, we will continue the decline down the slippery slide and become what the Treasurer, Mr Keating, referred to some years ago as a banana republic. We cannot afford any watering down of key reforms which must be carried out if we are not to become an island in a sea of Asian prosperity. I believe that language was used by the Prime Minister when giving gratuitous advice to and describing the future of Vietnam in recent months. I suggest to the Prime Minister that he looks in his own backyard.

For a country with our inherent wealth, the size of our gross foreign debt, our net foreign debt, interest rates on housing at 17 per cent and prime interest rates at 19.5 per cent is an absolute disgrace. It is a disgrace that the standards of living of all Australians, particularly of families, are at grave risk. The Treasurer talked about pulling levers, but the only lever he has pulled is the monetary lever to jack up interest rates in an attempt to stifle consumption. It would not be a problem if that consumption spending was on Australian manufactured goods. The simple reason why it is not being spent on Australian manufactured goods is that we can no longer compete. We are not manufacturing the goods and services that people wish to purchase. The old story that goods come from countries where labour is cheap no longer holds water. As most honourable senators would know, the average wage in Japan is $45,000 a year. Of course, we must export more and import less.

Those of our manufacturing industries which are competitive on the domestic market are not necessarily competitive on the export market. They have to run the gauntlet of high port costs and the infamous reputation we have for unreliability. That is the key thing, the unreliability. Compared to many of our competitors we are of course a long way from the major markets of the United States of America and Europe. Because we suffer the tyranny of distance-and I think we all recognise this, being a long way from those markets-our aim must be to make our ports not only equivalent in performance and cost to our competitors, but infinitely better. That has got to be the aim. Every Australian should be aiming to be the best in what he does. Reform on the waterfront is not the only area of micro-economic reform needed to get our country back on track, but I submit it is a vital start.

TALK.START.PARA: —It had no choice.

SPEECH.PARA: The second-round evidence and the further studies confirmed the fact that the waterfront industry is in urgent need of fundamental change. As the Commission observed in its preliminary findings, the industry displays the classic symptoms of an imperfect market:
ineffective management;
There is no mention from honourable senators opposite about the problems of inefficient management. It continues:
poor work force training and career arrangements;
There is no mention from the Opposition's remarks today about those matters. It goes on:
introspective industrial attitudes;
poor response to user needs;

That outlines succinctly what the Government will be dealing with when it brings down its report later this week based on the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report. I believe that the Opposition should at least have the good grace from time to time not always to belt the trade unions but to give them credit for the attitudinal changes they have made. I draw the attention of Senator Parer, in particular, to a document put out by the Waterside Workers Federation called `An industry in need of rejuvenation'. It makes it clear that it disagrees with some parts of the IAC report. After reading it we see it is willing to tackle in a large number of areas substantial change in its own industry. There has been a big change in trade unions in Australia over the last 10 years. They have been willing to tackle the need for change. Only a Labor government has the ability to deal with these changes and to work with the trade unions to achieve substantial change.

I want to conclude by giving an example of why I and this Government support major changes to our maritime and waterfront industries. Several weeks ago I was a member of a parliamentary delegation to New Zealand. While I was there I was at an official luncheon and sat next to the New Zealand Manager for General Motors-Holden's Ltd in that country. He explained to me that business was going very well in New Zealand. It was importing up to 500 cars a month from Australia, either in a fully assembled form or in parts ready to be assembled. He said that business was so good he would have thought they could have sold between 900 and 1,200 cars a month. I asked him why he could not. He said, `Obviously there is a boom in Australia at the moment and we cannot automatically get the orders we want from our own manufacturer. That could be overcome'. The biggest problem was in the availability of shipping to get the cars across the Tasman. I urge the Government to deal with the problem of the trans-Tasman shipping arrangements. That cannot go on under closer economic relations. There has to be a much more open and efficient system. Quite bluntly, it is costing jobs in the car industry in South Australia, my home State. If it could produce all the cars that were demanded in New Zealand it would mean more jobs at General Motors-Holden's Ltd in South Australia. When I got back I spoke to General Motors-Holden's about its problem and received further information about the difficulties it has. That is an arrangement the ship owners will not change, despite much pleading from General Motors-Holden's. When it gets the cars to Melbourne there is no guarantee that all the cars on the wharf will be loaded on to the ship. There can be changes at the last moment with these arrangements. It ill becomes the Opposition to put this motion forward and to criticise us for not doing enough when it had 30 years to do something and did nothing. In the last six years we have tackled micro-economic reform in a large number of areas and are continuing to do so. We have the guts to do it; the Opposition does not.

Yet if they do not, as a direct result of this Government's economic policies, they are expelled from the housing market. They are removed from any prospect of being able to own their own homes.

Less than a year ago the interest rate for a housing mortgage was 13 1/2 per cent. It is now 17 per cent, which is an increase of something like $2,800 a year on an average Sydney mortgage. It means that something like $56 a week extra is needed to meet the mortgage payments. Yet this Government is talking about tax cuts. Tax cuts will be only a tiny proportion of the huge increased interest bill being imposed upon Australians by this Government's high interest rate policy, a policy to which we have objected in the past and to which we will continue to object. We will continue to tell this Government that it must solve its problems by taking fiscal measures, by cutting its own spending, and not by hitting people who need housing in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing indicates the poverty of the economic policies of this Government more than what is happening in the housing area and some of the statistics which appear in the annual report on the Housing Assistance Act 1984. The report indicates, amongst other things, that around 40,000 people in Australia sleep out of doors and in refuges each night and that another 60,000 live on the verge of homelessness. As Senator Michael Baume pointed out a moment ago, 195,000 Australian households were on public housing waiting lists. The report points out that 14.5 per cent, or 762,000 income units, were in after-housing poverty in 1986-in other words, one in seven people, after they had paid for their housing, lived in poverty. Of those 762,000 income units 390,000, or approximately 50 per cent, were income units with dependent children.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have indicated on many previous occasions, the policy being pursued by this Government of growth for growth's sake lies fundamentally at the base of the housing problems which people experience in their everyday lives. The same applies to the in- ability of this Government to address properly the environmental problems that we face. I have pointed before to the fact that the gross domestic product has grown 2 1/4 times since the Second World War but, quite clearly, with respect to housing, we are not 2 1/4 times better off. In recent months, the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, has called for a substantial increase in the population of this country. He has called for an increase in population to 20 million by the year 2000. In other words, he wants a 25 per cent increase in population in only 10 years-that is, to add the present population of Adelaide to the present population of Sydney. Clearly, the amount of land in the Sydney area is limited. In a deregulated market, such an enormous increase in population can only lead to a substantial increase in the price of houses and land and, when we add to that a deregulated money market, it leads to an increase in the price of money and to high interest rates.

One of the defects in this growth-oriented economy in which we live is that very often we are counting the costs of that growth as benefits. Those people who are forced to live on the outskirts of already large cities such as Sydney find in their everyday lives that it is costing them more for travel and all those services which serve their housing needs. All those costs which they bear go down as additions to gross domestic product and are, therefore, counted in the national accounts as benefits.

The Government, through its deregulatory policy, is left with little else but forcing the price of money up-in other words, increasing the interest rates-as a way of controlling the economy. I would like to know from honourable senators on the Government side how those people who are building houses in Australia, using Australian materials and Australian labour, are adding to our foreign debt, and how cutting down the ability of those people to have houses will in any way impact on our foreign indebtedness. Quite clearly, this impacts most severely on those who are not able to invest in housing and therefore must pay for the housing in which they live at very high rates of interest.

I repeat: this Government's economic policy cannot address the fundamental problems which underlie the economic difficulties in which we find ourselves. Those difficulties are being expressed in the difficulty that ordinary people have in getting housing and in this Government's inability to address the very severe and growing environmental problems which this country faces.

I am most interested to see the size of this document entitled Department of Administrative Service: External Consultants 1987-88 which has been tabled this afternoon. It is some several inches thick and it concerns external consultants employed by the Department of Administrative Services between 1987 and 1988 with an expenditure of some $70m. I am interested to see it for two reasons: first, under the guidelines of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), pursuant to the Public Service Act, it is a requirement that departments publish particulars of these consultants as part of their annual reports. It is significant to say at this stage that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts is holding an inquiry into the annual reports of departments because two-thirds of all government departments-that is, secretaries to departments-although strictly required to include certain material in annual reports, have failed to so do. Indeed, they have been written to by the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet asking them to comply with the guidelines. The Committee has written to people and asked them to comply, and not even one response has been forthcoming. Consequently, this morning the Committee began its inquiry and has had the advantage of having Mr Codd, Dr Keating and others appear before it to be asked why the guidelines have not been complied with.

It is a significant matter because the total amount for procurement of goods and services in Australia annually is some $8 billion. There are some 3,500 people involved in spending that $8 billion. Here is a document accounting for $70m alone. The items included are diverse. There is a payment to a Mr Keddie, who is a consultant physiotherapist, for $90. He is being used by the Australian Construction Service central office because of a lack of in-house expertise. I find that curious. Then we go to something which is perhaps a correct use of consultants' skills. There was a need to assess the local wind and wave statistics at the submarine wharf, at a cost of $12,000.

As I go through the various items-as I said, the expenditure can range from $90 all the way through to over $100,000-what interests me is that under the Finance Regulations pursuant to the Audit Act there is a requirement that any expenditure in excess of $20,000-it was previously $10,000-requires a department to use the public tendering system. There is a provision under section 52aa (2) of the Finance Regulations to get an exemption from that procedure by getting a certificate from the Secretary to the Department of Finance. Similarly, there is a list of exempt categories where people may get expressions of interest and get quotes without going through the full tendering process.

The Public Accounts Committee has discerned that this requirement is observed rather in the breach than in the observance. So I would be most interested to know what percentage of this vast expenditure of some $70m has indeed met with the Finance Regulations or has been in breach. Many departments that have appeared before us have honoured this requirement in the breach rather than in the observance. It is a very serious matter because at a time when we are all speaking about letting the managers manage and asking for more efficiency in the Public Service there is an inability to comply with the law as it presently is. I think it is important that the Senate's attention be drawn to the fact that, if we are to see the Parliament being properly informed about the expenditure of public moneys which are meant to be for and on behalf of the public good, accountability needs to be stressed to both secretaries of departments and operatives within them. As I said, $8 billion is a lot of money to spend annually. This report alone represents $70m worth of expenditure. We do not know whether it has met with the requirements or whether those requirements have been honoured in the breach.
