On this occasion the Government is simply making sure that every possible option is examined throughly. That is appropriate Service procedure.
—Surely the Minister is not trying to convince the chamber that he has not changed the software package from that which was originally designed for the DESINE project?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, Senator Newman and I have a difference on fundamentals.
—Senator Watson this time.

—Sorry. There will be another difference on fundamentals with the honourable senator shortly, but let me tell Senator Watson that, on the differences with him on fundamentals, I am advised that there was no selected software package with DESINE.

—We have a unique situation in relation to IBM Australia Ltd. Is it true that IBM, having an officer within the DESINE evaluation section of the Department of Defence, has the power to veto the acquisition of other suppliers' material into the DESINE project? Secondly, could the Minister inform the chamber of those alternative bids that the IBM representative has already rejected?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there is no IBM representatives there yet.
—Until when?
—I will have to check on the date. I do not think it is relevant to look at a veto list. In any event, when the delegate does come he or she will not have a power of veto.
—Could the Minister tell me the role of the IBM representative? Where is he located at the present time?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The role of the person concerned is to advise the information systems division on the technology that the Government is evaluating and to determine whether IBM can supply it.
—Are any special arrangements being made to ensure that information of competitors is being kept confidential?
—Yes.
—Perhaps the Minister could tell us what the special arrangements are? I warn the Minister that vendors have approached me to say that they are certain that their prices are being disclosed to IBM.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I go back to the answer I gave a few moments ago when I said that there was no IBM representative there yet. If suppliers are going to Senator Newman, convinced that their prices are being supplied to IBM, then I would urge them to come forward with this information, or for Senator Newman to do so on their behalf, so that it might be investigated. It was clearly not anybody from IBM. It would have to be someone from the Department, and I am sure the Department would not do that. So I would be interested to hear of any information to that effect.
—I thank the Minister, but I asked what special arrangements were being made to keep competitors' information confidential. I did not get an answer.
—The simple answer is that the IBM representative will not be given the price component supplied by other companies who are bidding for any part of the work.

—If that information is being disclosed to IBM, it is not necessarily because there is an IBM person in the Department; perhaps there is somebody else in the middle. What special arrangements exist to keep competitors' information confidential?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no special arrangement. It is a standard arrangement that IBM is not given the price component. I have already pointed out that if those prices have been given to IBM, the information cannot have come from the IBM representative located there because as yet there is no such person; it must have come from within the Department. That is a very serious allegation. If anyone has any evidence to back it up, I wish that he or she would come forward.

—Could the Minister explain to the Senate the terms of the contract with IBM so far as it relates to the powers and responsibilities of its representative in the Defence Department on the DESINE project?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I have anything to add to the answer I gave a few moments ago, which was that the IBM representative is there to advise the Department on whether IBM can supply the equipment which is being examined at the time.
—So the Minister is saying that the contract provides that the officer in place decides whether IBM can supply the goods. If it can supply the goods or software, then does it get the contract?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am not saying that. What I am saying is that the person will be there to provide the advice. The Department then has the option of accepting or rejecting the advice.
—If the competitors' prices are not disclosed to IBM, how can IBM determine-and, after all, I understand it does have a role of determining-whether it will allow the exemption under DESINE?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am answering the same questions a number of times in a row.
—No, you are not.

—Nonetheless, if that is required, I am happy to do so. Senator Newman is ascribing to the IBM representative a power that he or she cannot have. He or she will not be deciding anything; he or she will be advising. It will still be up to the Department to make the decision in the end, not the person from IBM. Now that that fundamental misconception is out of the road, I do not understand what the problem is. If the only thing that IBM is doing is giving advice, then I do not believe that any great problem exists.
—Perhaps the Minister will bear with my slow response and explain to us what the procedure is for IBM to approve any exemption under DESINE.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the problem-IBM does not approve the exemption. This is the third time that I have said it. It does not veto and it does not approve; it gives advice.
—Is the Minister now categorically denying that IBM has a right of veto?
—Yes, that is exactly what I am doing. I have just checked that advice for the fourth time, and the answer keeps coming back the same.
—Therefore, in what circumstances will IBM get the work where both IBM and somebody else can supply the necessary software and do the necessary work?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —If IBM can provide a satisfactory system at the contract price, then it will get the job.
—Therefore, nobody else can compete?
—That is correct, that is in the terms of the original contract.
—It is exclusive to IBM now, so long as it can perform.
—If IBM can come up with the goods that meet the requirements, then it gets the job. Those have always been the terms of the contract.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6.31 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Am I right in thinking that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has got an answer for me now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner break I think we were examining the question of possible exemptions. I would like to go through those. They include the following sorts of applications: small enhancements where it is clear that they do not undermine the long term strategy; specialist classified systems involving links with allies; embedded systems, such as computers in the Anzac ships; and where the DESINE solution is clearly unsuitable in respect of project cost, time and function. There is no intention to make exemptions easy to obtain, but they do exist, they are possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I would like to take him a bit further down the track about exemptions, and I quote from an internal Department of Defence document issued on 12 April this year, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: Exemptions from IBM. Grounds for exemptions are solutions from the contract, which after consultation with IBM are clearly unsuitable in terms of functionality, or time, or in terms of cost when considered in the context of the total costs of the project, as distinct from the price of the equipment. In these circumstances it will be necessary for the project manager to consult with IBM and would need a case demonstrating clear unsuitability of the IBM solution to warrant a non IBM solution. IBM agreement to this case should be sought although in unusual circumstances Defence might find cause to opt for a non IBM solution without IBM agreement.

In the light of the Minister's statement before dinner, that IBM Australia Ltd had no veto, or words to that effect, would not the advice which he received before dinner have to be considered to be quite inaccurate in the light of this quotation from this document of 12 April, `IBM agreement . . . should be sought although in unusual circumstances Defence might find cause to opt for a non-IBM solution without IBM agreement'? In other words, most times it has got to be with IBM agreement, except in very special circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can say that I would have been badly advised were it not the case that the document from which Senator Newman is quoting has been revised. As a result of that revision, the consultation with IBM that she refers to is now no longer needed when the Department is looking at exemptions.
—May I have a copy of the new clause that covers this same area?

—I am trying to clarify when I can provide the document. The document will certainly be provided. It is in that memorandum to which we referred earlier. We have given an undertaking to provide it, and it will be provided within a week.
—Could I have the date of the document?
—I am advised that it does not have a date on it at all.
—I wonder whether the Minister could answer more generally what benefit to the Commonwealth is seen from giving this enormous contract to IBM? Why all of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The basis for the project is to enable a computer system across all the various parts within Defence so that they can communicate with each other. It is a very broad objective. If we are going to meet such an objective, then obviously if we are asking for one company to do it, it must be big by nature-big it is.
—Isn't it like buying submarines? So long as it is Swedish, we will buy it. With computers, if it is IBM we will buy it.

—Can we debate the submarines a little later on? I am having enough trouble with the computers before I hit the submarines. On the question of the computers, I think we have to re-emphasise that this system was put to tender, and IBM won it. There cannot be any question about the tender system. It was open, it was above board and IBM won. Since it has won, the honourable senator is now querying not only its right to have won, but also the Government's right to negotiate with it after it has won. I cannot quite understand how she gets around to doing that. It has got every right now to insist on the contract with it being met.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer. Of course I have a number of queries, and I would query the wisdom first of all of putting such a large contract into one package which, I believe, will be very difficult for the Department to administer effectively. I question the need for the compatibility or the interoperability of so many systems throughout the Department. The existing arrangements are not necessarily disadvantageous. I question the special privileged position which IBM will achieve five years down the track when other tenderers might wish to try again for a tender with the Department. IBM will be very clearly in the box seat for any extension of the contractual arrangements. In the meantime, I also query the additional cost to the Commonwealth, as I believe it will be quite massive, instead of upgrading existing equipment within the Department, requiring it to be brought into the DESINE system. So there are a number of quite serious concerns which the Minister should recognise.

SPEECH.PARA: My next question relates to new technology. In the Estimates Committee hearing I asked whether the Department agreed that new technology must be acquired through open tendering to achieve the most competitive price for the taxpayer. This is another very real concern as to how the Department will in fact acquire new technology along the way. I understand that vendors are being told that new technology not anticipated by the DESINE request for tender will automatically be included in the DESINE contract and supplied by IBM. Just how is one going to get competitive prices unless one can put to tender for specific systems? I think the Department's answer to this was very evasive. I would like the Minister to give the chamber an assurance that new technology will be acquired by the Department through competitive tenders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I can give that guarantee. We have to go back to the contract that has been negotiated with IBM. That does allow for future technologies to be included, provided of course they conform with DESINE. So I do not know how I can give a further undertaking other than that. But I want to comment on some of the matters that the honourable senator has raised. If she is looking at benefit to the Government, this tender process and its evaluation were very thorough. It conformed with the processes that were outlined by the Department of Administrative Services. The local content elements of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce that are insisted upon in these negotiations were looked at very thoroughly. At the end of all this it was the view that IBM was a clear and convincing winner. We must go back to that as the basis for the Government's actions since then. Obviously some of the companies that did not win, some of those that were on the outside looking in-I will not use President Johnson's analogy-have obviously been questioning the scope of the philosophy in the first place and its implementation. There is a suggestion that some of those companies are offering artificially low prices in a bid to undermine the original contract. Whatever is done from now on, however, obviously the Government will not be in a position to accept anything which would undermine the philosophy behind the decision.

—I appreciate that the Minister is skirting around the matters I raised. I thought he was going to come to grips with the serious questions I raised. If he is unable to do that I will move on to the question of new technology because he did not come to grips with that either. I am talking about the constant and racing new developments that are occurring in this area and from which the Department is ready to shut itself off because of the necessity to be tied into one firm. The question of upgrading existing equipment will mean that there will be no requirement for the Department to look for the newest technology because of being tied in to IBM. I would like it clearly on the record that the Minister not able to give me an assurance that new technology would be acquired and that it would be through competitive tenders. It would be done through this backdoor arrangement, with IBM being chatted up to see what it has to say about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I said before that the contract obviously must be observed and that the Government would be at pains to observe it. The contract with IBM does allow for future technologies to be included as they emerge. They will be provided by IBM where its technology is suitable but, if not, other new technology can be tendered for once again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —My question relates to contract software and the area we covered earlier with Senator Watson when we established that there is a difficulty for companies other than IBM to gain contracts for supply if IBM says it has the ability to supply. I take the Minister directly to the supply system redevelopment project, particularly to the expressions of interest which were sought in July last year. I take the Minister more particularly to the trials which will begin next Monday for the three companies which have been distilled from the people who originally showed expressions of interest. They will be going through a fortnight's trial at very great expense to them so see whether they may be eligible for software contracts. This work, in terms of value to an Australian company as distinct from an overseas company, could be worth some $20m. We are not talking about peanuts. We are talking about the problem where, under the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce guidelines, with partnerships for development and offsets-I believe IBM is a partner-we are supposed to see spin-offs and benefits for the Australian economy and Australian development as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly, the way this contract is structured means that the bias is in favour of imported software and not indigenous software. I would very much like to hear the Minister's comments on what might transpire, whichever of these three companies is successful, at the end of the two week trial. It is open to IBM to say that one or other of the successful people simply do not fit with its architecture and effectively to veto that company being given the work. I would enjoy hearing the Minister's comments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I answer those questions from Senator Bishop, I will answer a question she raised before the dinner break concerning Mr Seymour rewriting the tender documents. The difficulty is that Mr Seymour left the Department of Defence in 1984 and the documents were written in 1986. I do not think he did what Senator Bishop suggests, but if she has any further information I would be happy to have a look at it.

SPEECH.PARA: To return to this other question, which relates to software, the project we are discussing is about an overall computing environment; it is not specific.

TALK.START.PARA: —Environment?

—I am the environment Minister, so I am getting closer to my direct influence. As such, certain types of software are obviously going to be available under the contract. That will not include some major applications software. The example of that is the one Senator Bishop raised. If she is looking at commercial packages which might be used in the supply systems project, they are in that category.
—Which category is that?

—In the category of not being included in the original project environment. Some types of software are available under the contract but not every type. The application software Senator Bishop is referring to is in that category. A decision on the supply systems project applications software will be based on the request for tender now being evaluated.

SPEECH.PARA: As I am on my feet I will cover those questions of cost effectiveness which were raised earlier. That was part of the basis upon which IBM was selected. As a result of that selection, under normal circumstances the order will go to IBM if it can supply from the product list and if there is no exemption. I will not go through the exemptions again. Perhaps there is some confusion between a software purchase--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that from the non-DESINE product list?
—I am talking about the DESINE product list, as far as I know.
—There are two IBM lists.

—I am reassured that we are talking only about the DESINE list. If that were not the case I would give up. In the case of what Senator Watson had to say before and what Senator Bishop is saying now, perhaps there is a confusion between the software purchase, such as that for the supply systems project, and a software listing under the DESINE contract. I think that is the main answer to what Senator Bishop is asking.

—The Minister referred earlier to the fact that there were some disgruntled members of the computer industry who were taking an interest in this matter. I assure the Minister that it is not just the computer industry that is taking an interest. The Opposition is taking a close interest in it, but so are the Armed Services. Could the Minister say whether the Armed Services want Unix?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether the Services want it. But in any case at the moment that does not really matter because we have not ruled it out.
—Have the Services argued within the Department to have this product incorporated in their acquisitions list?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pending establishment of DESINE standards, some areas of defence, civilian and military, adopted Unix as an interim standard for certain applications because it offered, among other things, integrated office automation facilities. There has been no unanimity in support of Unix certainly across all applications. There is no international standard for Unix.
—I think that we could probably keep going all night. The Minister might improve his reading by the end of the evening.
—I thought I did rather well.
—If the Minister has got the time, so have we.
—Perhaps next time he could put it in iambic pentameter.

—I think those words are too big for the Minister, Senator. Let me take this matter a little further. The Minister was talking about security and Unix. I would point out that Unix has at least as good security as a commercial system and DESINE is a commercial system. The advice the Minister gave earlier might need to be revised. One of the reasons for not proceeding with Unix was the question of security.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —IBM offers security within the overall application of DESINE. Unix does not.
—Would the Minister not like to reassess that answer?
—I am advised that my answer is correct.
—What were the reasons that led to a working party being established to review Unix when, according to the Department, it was evaluated during the DESINE tender process?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that has been answered in part already. A few moments ago I acknowledged that some parts of the Department are looking at Unix and that there was no unanimity of support for it; but developments are still going on with it. That is why a working party has been set up. We will evaluate results of the working party and make a decision in two to three months when it reports.

—I think that the Minister has heard only the first part of the question. I asked what were the reasons that led to a working party to review Unix when, according to the Department, it was evaluated during the DESINE tender process. Why is that being done again?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —None of the three final tenderers offered Unix, and, in any event, as I said, developments are proceeding with it all the time.
—Were the Services involved in the evaluation of Unix during the DESINE tender process?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, there were Service representatives on the team which did the evaluation.
—Could the Minister please give me some more details?
—I am advised that there was one from each of the Services.
—Throughout the entire evaluation process?
—I shall have to take that question on notice.

—Perhaps in taking the question on notice the Minister could also tell me who they were. I would also draw the Minister's attention to a question that I put on notice on Friday to make it easier for the Department. I asked for details on the $25m stated by the Department for Unix based systems. I asked for a break-up listing hardware costs, software costs, software development costs, any consultancy costs, communication costs, training costs, et cetera. I wanted a total cost identification over the life period of all Unix based systems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can give Senator Newman an answer in part, but it will not satisfy her because it is not full. I am advised that the Department is still working on a full response to Senator Newman's question. In so far as the answer goes, let me say that the major elements were a variety of equipment for Navy, adding to an estimated $15m. The remainder was for the RAAF standard word and administrative processing system project, RSWAPS. This included hardware, software, one year of maintenance and training. Further detail can and will be provided. However, this will take a little time and some information may be difficult to obtain.
—How long is a little time in the eye of the Department?
—Two weeks.

—A question was asked in the Estimates Committee about our major allies having standardised on Unix, and we referred to this matter earlier today. I refer to question 108 in the Estimates Committee hearings. It asked whether the investment and the fact that our major allies have standardised on Unix would be taken into account when the Department decided on it, or is this another case where cost-effectiveness is not being considered? I was told that the Department would take into account the current defence investment in Unix during its deliberations. The Minister will note that his Department also responded by stating that Defence has investments in many other different systems beyond Unix. Will the Minister guarantee that these investments will similarly be taken into account?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Existing investments will be a factor in some enhancements, final extensions and component replacements needed for current equipments before they or the application system running on them reach the end of their economic life.
—It was difficult, with the Minister's intonation, to work out what he was saying. In what way will these investments be taken into account? Have I missed the point?

—What this means is that it may be the case that if there are existing systems that are worth a great deal, it may be worth looking at the purchase of systems related to them. To that extent existing investments will be taken into account. At no stage would that be allowed to undermine the strategy of project DESINE.
—What is the total value of current investments?
—I will have to take that on notice.

—I thought that would have been easy. I also asked on notice on Friday, to assist the Department, whether it could provide detailed figures for the value of the current investments for the major defence applications. Therefore, I am surprised that the Department does not have information here about current investments. Based on the Department's evidence at the Public Accounts Committee, these should run into hundreds of millions of dollars, I would have thought. Has the Minister that information?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not have that information. It is true that Senator Newman asked a question on notice about the matter, but that question has some serious definitional problems-for example, for computer systems that may be part of other systems. It has methodological problems. There is also the problem of replacement value versus historical cost valuation. TALK.START.PARA: —It is purely fortuitous that we have had so much about the decision-making process in relation to one program occupying the time of this Committee. I would like to make a few general observations about the decision-making process and then ask a question. I was probably the chief mover for the management report that the Joint Committee prepared a while ago and, in the course of preparing that report, we went through the decision-making process-I might say in passing that it is a great loss to the country that the Government has chosen to suppress that report-and started to address some of the great inefficiencies in the administration of the Department of Defence. Hopefully, the way the climate is going politically, as soon as the Government gets the courage to go to the polls, we will be able to address that, re-form that huge conurbation of human beings and paper over the creek here, clean up the Russell Hill complex, get something efficient and get some more money into the Services.

SPEECH.PARA: Very simply, we have a very elaborate decision-making process. The Department of Defence does not buy anything on the spur of the moment. An enormous amount of analysis goes into anything about the need, first of all, which way it can be met, what is the best way of doing it, things are prioritised within the Department and all the facets in the acquisition process are very carefully defined. In the report we pointed out that there were at least four stages: the definition of the requirement; organising the means to achieve the stated requirement; contracting for the purchase of new equipment, and weapons systems; and post-contract administration.

We have a heap of committees as well. It is known as analysis by paralysis and it really is. Something like 17 committees have to be gone through before anything of any size is bought. The chief one is the Defence Operational Concepts and Capabilities Committee, then the Force Structure Committee, Defence Source Definition Committee and finally the Defence Force Definition Committee before it finally goes to the Minister in Cabinet for purchase.

Despite having this huge, cumbersome and enormously analytical system the decisions that are coming out are not good in a number of cases. It is a fact that decisions have been overturned. When probably millions of dollars have been invested in decisions and a huge investment has been made in the bureaucracy in churning these things around, decisions come out immaculately researched and justified in every sense, and they are turned around at the whim of the Cabinet or a Minister. One very good example of that was the PC7 aircraft decision. Recommendations for the new trainer were that we buy the PC7. Somehow or other, along the line, when it came to signing the contract or when it came out of Cabinet, it was the PC9 aircraft, which was vastly more expensive, vastly more sophisticated and not the aircraft that the Air Force wanted.

Apart from decisions being overturned, we have also had wrong decisions being made. I accept that while my first assertion is fact, the second is a matter of opinion and I will not take the time of the Committee in debating my opinions on where the wrong decisions have been made. I do, however, want to relate the decision-making process to the announcement made earlier this year to buy five Falcon 900 series jet aircraft for 34 Squadron to provide the VIP Fleet. Again the recommendation from the Department of Defence was to buy the Canadair Challenger aircraft. The decision was overturned in Cabinet by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The whim of the Prime Minister was quite simple. Because it had three engines it had to be safer than something with two engines. I imagine that if a person is Prime Minister or, as Patrick Cook calls him, Little Caesar, he has to make the odd decision on his own from time to time. Maybe the Prime Minister is entitled to turn over the advice of the Department. The other example is when Senator Newman and I had to move the censure motion against Senator Richardson over the appointment of a lieutenant-general for Namibia--

TALK.START.PARA: —Sinai.

—Sinai, was it-despite the fact that we have 44 two-stars and above in this huge, over-ranked Defence Force, which is far more than we ever had at the peak of the Second World War. Be that as it may, let me return to the VIP Fleet in 34 Squadron. It may well be argued that the chosen aircraft, the Falcon 900s, are better than the upgraded Challengers that the Air Force wanted. It is also true that the Challengers would do some things better than the Falcons. The difference in cost simply is not worth it.

SPEECH.PARA: We have an Air Force that is strapped for funds, the way both the Navy and the Army are. The provision of VIP aircraft is very much at the bottom of the priorities of the Air Force. What went on? Why was the Prime Minister allowed to get away with this personal whim? I suspect that one of the reasons he was able to get away with it was the fact that the Department had not done any accurate costing on the whole program. Despite its numerous protestations that it has costed out 34 Squadron over the years-and I have taken an interest in the matter-it simply does not have a database to work upon. If it does not have a database with the old aircraft in the squadron, it simply cannot make comparisons with new purchases and new systems.

Over the years I have repeatedly asked what it cost to keep 34 Squadron going. I have owned aircraft for over 20 years, so I have more than a little insight into what the overheads may be. This year I again asked the question. The reply which was posted to me was to the effect that it cost $2.6m for fuel, $3m for spares, $1.3m for contractor servicing, and $1.2m for incidentals such as handling charges, crew travel and catering, giving an aggregate cost of $8.1m per annum to run the present 34 Squadron. That is as comprehensive a figure as we have ever received from the Department and it is also utterly meaningless because it does nothing to give the true cost of operating those aircraft per hour, per year or by whatever standards one wants to apply. If one does not have that figure, one cannot come up with any other system and claim that it is more efficient, which is what the Government is doing with its leasing agreement.

The figure we have received from the Department does not include the cost of personnel, buildings and aircraft. They happen to be the big expenses, not fuel. Unless the Air Force knows, and unless the Department of Defence knows, how many man-hours and how many personnel it takes to support the aircraft in the present squadron, a very large fraction of their overheads is not determined. Unless they know the capital cost of the aircraft, which is the largest fraction, and amortise those over the life of type, again they cannot come up with any costing. In the face of this total absence of hard data-which should be available, given the resources of the Department to work it out-the Department proceeds with the lease of five new aircraft and tells us that this is cheaper.

There was an allegation earlier that some of the Minister's comments on computer technology and procedures were gobbledegook. The answer the Department gave, in response to a question of mine as to how it arrived at the justification for spending $203m for the lease of those five aircraft for 10 years, that that was the cost effective way to go is a meaningless reply. I do not know the cost of a Falcon 900 aircraft but I imagine that if a government went to the manufacturer and said it wanted to buy five of them, it would buy the five of them for a figure very close to the figure of $203m that we are paying for the lease of these aircraft over 10 years. I doubt very much that those aircraft, on a government purchase basis and a block basis of five which, after all, is a big buy, would not be available for somewhere around the $40m mark each. Nevertheless, we have gone ahead with a leasing agreement and that leasing agreement does not cover maintenance. It has gone out on a three-year tender to the supplier of the aircraft, Hawker Pacific Pty Ltd, at a cost of $3m, $7m or $8m-I forget what the figure was.

Essentially, at the end of the day we have a cost of something like $25m a year to the taxpayer for five aircraft which are used only to fly the Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition and senior Ministers around Australia. There is no defence element at all. It has nothing to do with the Air Force. Whether the Government recovers the money from the user departments, whether the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet pays for the cost of those aircraft against a notional charge value, is absolutely irrelevant. The taxpayer is paying for them. In the face of those bungled accounting measures, I would like to know how the Minister can claim that this is the most cost effective way of running what is essentially just an air charter operation for a very small clientele.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last thing I want to see is the resources of the Department expended in working out accurate costings on the history of 34 Squadron. Quite clearly that should have been done in the past. It is quite pointless to do it now. Senator Richardson's argument about shared facilities is, with respect, quite irrelevant. All that is being shared is a few buildings; the maintenance and support of the aircraft are not being shared.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department should have adopted the cost accounting techniques that have been common practice in the airline industry for 30 or 40 years. The airline industry knows precisely what it costs per hour to fly. It knows what it costs in fuel, spares, crew training, crew support-the whole lot. The Air Force has never done this and it can argue that it really does not matter, but it does matter. One of the reasons why the F18s were purchased was the reduced maintenance man-hours and the quantum jump in mean time between failures on all the major components-not only engines but the radar and other equipment. It is important for the Air Force, the Army and the Navy to know what highly expensive equipment is going to cost so that they may stay on line through the decade or two decades during which the equipment will be used. I will not take the matter any further. The point is that the Government does not have the database on which to make the confident predictions that Senator Richardson and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) have made-that what we have is the cheapest way to go. It may or may not be. The point is that the Minister cannot prove it.

On the question of this decision-making process, I want to talk a little about the Cockatoo Island mess-up. Cockatoo Island is one of Australia's old dockyards. It has two graving docks, and it has been repairing ships for probably 100 years. It has had varied ownership and a varied commercial history, but since we bought the Oberon class submarines it has provided all the support for them. It also did the submarine weapons update-a brilliant Australian program-and completed it very successfully, on contract and on time. All the intermediate level maintenance and major refits that it has carried out since the Oberons came into service have been faultless. The Oberons will go out of service in the immediate future-though I think that it will be a little longer than the Government, having bought this lemon of a submarine from the Swedes, thinks. The Government had a hang-up about the Swedish socialist governments, and no-one else could get a look-in.

I am advised that the detailed drawings have not yet been delivered to the manufacturer in South Australia, despite the fact that, initially, the whole submarine was going to be built in Australia. The proposition that the bow section and the hull section under the sail or conning tower was to be built in Sweden seemed to create some big problems. I am advised that the Swedes themselves do not know how to design those sections. They went to the Germans for some advice, but the Germans would not help them. It is not surprising that the Swedes do not know how to design those sections, because they have never built anything even half as large as the boat we wanted. However, that is irrelevant.

Here, we had Cockatoo Island supporting the Oberons, which are going out of service. If the Government is correct, the first of the new Swedish 471 submarines will be launched in 1993, and the Oberons will progressively come out of service from then. The point is that there is a short and finite period during which the Oberons have to be maintained, and we have a proved support facility. What does the Government do? It turns round and says that it will sell Cockatoo Island, despite the fact that the lease agreement with ANI runs until 1992 or 1993. The Government got an agreement with ANI that if it crossed its palms with silver it would relinquish the lease contract, and it is going for sale at the moment.

There is simply no reason for selling Cockatoo Island. The Government, being strapped for money, is out to sell every possible bit of real estate that the Services own. Of course, some of the real estate in Sydney is highly desirable. It is a very wrong decision, and an extremely short-sighted one. The Australian Defence Services are in the business of looking after the defence of this country for hundreds of years ahead, and the short-term pressures of the economic mismanagement and incompetence of this Government do not justify stripping them of sites that they will clearly need for the foreseeable future.

But there is this pressure to liquidise assets. No doubt the Government has been approached by some of its real estate mates: `This is a good site for a block of flats'. No doubt that is what gave rise to the decision to sell Cockatoo Island. Of course, that has been compounded by Mr Beazley's pork-barrelling of Western Australia and Fremantle, behind the pretence of a two-ocean Navy. We have no quarrel with the concept of a two-ocean Navy, and least of all do we have any quarrel with the support facilities in the west to operate the Navy-indeed, all three Services. That is just common sense. But, in relation to something like the maintenance of the submarines, to draw up a tender as this one was drawn up, and to design the document so that only Western Australians-in fact, only one company in Western Australia-could tender, when there is only this very short-term need, is very wrong. This takes me back to the difficulties that the Minister was in when he tried to explain why IBM had such a stranglehold on the DESINE contract. It seems to be part of the distressing tendency of the Government to do things for its friends-things which I am quite sure the corporate body of the Department of Defence would not have a bar of.
The first submarine-Oxley-was overhauled in the early part of this year. I asked some questions about that because there were some significant problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was overhauled in Cockburn.

—Well, somewhere in Western Australia. It is all over there in the saltpan country. There were a number of problems. It is interesting to note the Navy's written response to my question. It was a rather bland response-a reference to a leaking seal on one of the propeller shafts, and a bit of anti-fouling paint coming off. I repeated the question in the chamber, and Senator Richardson was good enough to give me Mr Beazley's response. Responding in the House of Representatives to a dorothy dixer, Mr Beazley went into the matter in a great more detail. The claims that I had made about the hull being damaged, and so on, were all supported. What I am concerned about is the secrecy. Senator Newman asked what was the pilot strength of squadrons 3, 75 and 77 of the RAAF. The written reply was that, in the interests of national security, the information could not be revealed. That is absolute nonsense, but it is typical of the Government's responses to so many questions about defence. Its initial response to questions on the submarine program, made on the basis of secrecy, is meaningless. It is not concerned about national secrecy; but, in what it says, there is evidence of its own incompetence in these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned also about the degree of the Government's influence over the press. Quite clearly, there is a degree of censorship on press reporting of defence matters. When I asked Senator Richardson in the chamber about the consequences of the docking operation in Western Australia, a large number of press people phoned me or came to my office. Every one of those journalists, when I had explained the situation, said `I must contact Mr Beazley's office'. That matter was not reported, except in Western Australia. All of the east coast press were suppressed. This links up with the dishonesty that is evident in the Department. So many ministerial statements in the defence field now indicate that decisions are taken on the advice of the Chief of the Defence Force (CDF) and the Secretary, when, patently, that is not true.

I cite the Joint Committee's report on wastage. We made the point that too high a proportion of the defence vote now goes into capital equipment and that not enough is left for human resources, and the answer is to increase the vote. But the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Simmons), in his formal reply, many months later-it was tabled a couple of weeks ago-was to the effect that that decision was based on the advice the CDF and the Secretary had tendered to the Minister. That is not true. The Minister is saying to the Department, `You have $X billion. We are going to buy that equipment because we have contractual obligations. You can fit in the other things you have to do out of what is left over'. It is quite dishonest for the Minister to do that.

The recent example of the Chinooks was again prefaced by a statement that the advice that the Minister had received from the CDF and the Secretary was that the Chinooks were no longer required. In reality the CDF and the Secretary were again told, `This is your budget. You have got to cut so much out to stay alive'. That is how we got to the absurd situation, very much against the national interest, in which the Chinooks were sacrificed. This has come up since the Senate Estimates hearings. I raised some questions there.

I just want to put a few points on the record. The position with the Chinooks is that there are 11 47Cs. The C model is no longer supported with spares. Within a year or two, we will not be able to fly those aircraft because no more spare parts are being made for them. The Americans had a look at it and decided that it had a good air- frame. They have gone to a D model. They have completely gutted the Chinooks and put in new rotors, new engines, new transmissions and new instrumentation. That has been done for about $US8m to $US9m each. The Minister claims that for us to do it in Australia it would cost $200m. That may be true. I think it is a high figure but for that we get something that is quite essential for the Australian operational doctrine. We get a helicopter which has about half the maintenance man hours per flying hour of the C model and twice the range and twice the payload. That would cost $200m. That capability would cost at least four or five times as much if we had to go on the market in a year or two and replace them-as we surely will have to.

That aircraft is very important in Army operations. It is the only rotary wing aircraft we have that will lift the 155 millimetre medium artillery gun. It has an essential role in ammunition supply, in fuel tanks, bladder cell supplies, supplies in general and in troop transport. Given that there is very little self-propelled armour and artillery and a general shortage of mobility in this country for the operational deployment force, it is an essential national asset. Let us forget all the business about flood rescue, sea rescue and the rest of it; that is a secondary role, important though it might be. We are in this mess because the Government bungled the helicopter decision years ago when it gave the Black Hawks to the Army. I have a very high regard for the Army Aviation Regiment. I spent a couple of days flying with it at the end of last year. It is a superb unit. But the decision to give it the helicopters led to an enormous degree of irritation, to put it euphemistically, in the Royal Australian Air Force and a great fall in morale. The Army will be the sufferers this time with the loss of the Chinook capability. The question I ask is: What sort of a detailed submission was prepared by the Department which justified the Minister saying that he had the support of the Department to get rid of those aircraft?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator MacGibbon's wide-ranging speech requires a number of answers. The first point I want to raise is on media censorship. In six years in this place I have not heard a more extraordinary allegation than the one made tonight to the effect that, having spoken to Senator MacGibbon, journalists had the hide to want to check their story with the Minister and then would not run Senator MacGibbon's allegations. Anyone who has a dud story that does not stack up does not get a credit. Every journalist in the gallery has a duty to at least check the other side of the argument. Senator MacGibbon's arrogance is such that he cannot stand being disputed. But he was disputed on that occasion, and he was found wanting. The journalists in the gallery agree with what I am saying, and they would not run a dud story. That is fine; that is the game we all play. If I put out a statement which attacked the Opposition, I would never expect someone in the gallery not to go to the Opposition and ask for a comment. At times, we all have to suffer the indignity that journalists just might not agree with us. What a huge deal. This is not about censorship; it is about a free press and democracy. I wonder whether Senator MacGibbon supports either principle.

SPEECH.PARA: If I can remember back so far, I think we started on this long ranging discourse on the question of the VIP aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be hard for you with your neuronal capacity.

—I think it just about matches yours. There was the question of the five Falcons and Senator MacGibbon's assertions about the inability of the Department to provide what he considers to be appropriate expenditure details. The Department is happy to provide its costings for the future operations of the five new aircraft. As I said, given that there will have to be some assumptions based on guesswork, not on facts, those will be provided to the honourable senator, and the Department will begin working on them.

SPEECH.PARA: The next issue that Senator MacGibbon covered in some detail was Cockatoo Island. Senator MacGibbon has shown a continuing interest in the Oberon submarines. It is not the first time that he has criticised any decision to have their maintenance carried out in Western Australia. I do not hate Western Australia or Western Australians and cannot see any reason for his attack on that fine State. Senator MacGibbon is wrong when he suggests that the Minister or the Department, or both, are involved in an exercise of coming up with a request for tender (RFT) which can only be met by one company. The Defence Source Definition Committee has considered a report produced for departmental consideration on this question. It has met a couple of times over the past few weeks to complete its deliberations. It has recommended that three companies be short-listed and invited to tender for the work. The RFT will be issued by 1 July this year. It is hoped that responses will close three months later. There is no great magic about that. Once again, the Government is acting properly in making sure that as many companies as possible are given the opportunity to tender. It is interesting to note-again, it is something that Government spokesmen have been saying for some time now-that whenever any attempt is made by the Government to sell off any government enterprise it is immediately criticised by the Opposition, which runs counter, of course, to its professed philosophy.

We have moved from aeroplanes through to submarines, then to helicopters and back to the decision on the Chinooks. It is true that that decision was taken on the recommendation of the Department of Defence. The Department had to consider all the options available. I would not have thought that the answers which have so far been given have precluded costs being a factor in the decision; they obviously were. The upgrade which Senator MacGibbon has mentioned from a C model to a D model was estimated to cost in the region of $200m. That was the Defence Department's estimate. I suppose Senator MacGibbon could try to vary that, but it was a very, very substantial amount of money. The Defence Department then had to look at whether there was justification for that sort of upgrade, particularly when the Black Hawk could cover practically every operation that the Chinook would be involved in. The great majority of the tasks of the Chinook can be performed by the Black Hawk. In the light of the costs of the upgrade and the fact that the Black Hawk can pretty well do what the Chinook can do, then the Department, regretfully-I do not think there was joy in the decision-recommended to the Minister that the Chinooks should go. I think that is responsible management rather than any problem.

In finishing my response, I want to turn to the question of the submarines and the Swedes. The fact is that the Department recommended the Swedes. When I look to my left at this collection of advisers here, I do not think I am looking at a bunch of rabid socialists besotted by the Swedes; I doubt that very much. There was a very lengthy technical assessment. I do not remember how long it took, but it went on for a very long time and it was no easy decision. Of course there were tremendous lobbying efforts from all concerned. But as I recall it the lobbying was not coming from the Swedes or the Germans but rather from the States.

State governments, all over Australia, were filling aircraft to Canberra with Ministers and advisers who were running around the corridors of this place pleading with governments about where to put the main part of these contracts, where the main benefits would go, rather than putting forward arguments about whether the right technology was being chosen. The Defence Department had the opportunity, in the absence of all those sorts of representations, to look solely at the issue of technical capabilities, and came down with the recommendation for the Swedes. I am not aware of any problems of great magnitude with that project. Obviously with massive projects there are always going to be some hiccups. Not everything goes smoothly when we are spending hundreds of millions or billions of dollars. None the less, the project is proceeding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad the Minister brought up the business about the States lobbying for the submarine program, because this was the Government's intention, to take the argument away from the technical suitability or the capabilities of the design and turn it into an auction, playing on the cupidity of the various State Premiers. We had this most unseemly public competition before the submarine decision as to whether it would be South Australia, Victoria or New South Wales. The technical elements of the decision were totally suppressed, and I believe they were suppressed intentionally by the Government because it did not want them exposed for examination. Of course it just happened that poor old Mr Bannon was coming up for an election. He was a bit shaky, so a bit more Beazley pork-barrelling, and surprise, surprise, the State with no heavy engineering capability, the State with no ship building capability, gets the bonus and Mr Bannon wins the election.

SPEECH.PARA: We have the same thing happening with New South Wales and Victoria at the present time with the Anzac ship program. We should not be in that position. These are national matters, they are not matters to be debated between Premiers as to whether they can do something better than someone else. Let us work out what is best for the country, first of all from the design point of view, and let us see who can build them most efficiently. Again on the management situation, the Government made a very bad mistake when it looked at, and selected, only two yards in Australia, a consortium at Newcastle and a consortium at Williamstown in Victoria. It said, `Those are the two which are going to build this new Anzac frigate. You get yourself designers and then we will look at the package when you have worked it up'. The decision making is on at the present time.

So we have a yard in Victoria, which some people would probably argue is the better of the two yards, but with a Third World designed ship to sell. We have a yard in New South Wales that has yet to prove itself in some ways, with a very well designed ship. It is quite wrong to do that. They are locked in and there is no flexibility at all. We should have decided what sort of ship we wanted, worked out the design, and then put it out to tender. But I divert on that.

The argument that the Minister is making about the Chinooks is technically quite wrong. It is not true to say that anything the Chinooks can do, the Black Hawks can do. They simply cannot. They cannot lift even half the load, and the Army does have a requirement for those heavy loads. It is not for only weapons; it is for stores, vehicles and all sorts of things. To say that the Black Hawk will do nearly all of the things that the Chinook will do is meaningless unless one thinks that if it flies it is doing the same task, so let us leave it at that.

I go back to the request for tender document. I happen to have in my possession the official publication of the request for tender that was issued by the Government in relation to the intermediate level docking of the Oberon boats. The only organisations which are permitted to tender are the Garden Island dockyard on the east coast and the shipyards in the Fremantle-Perth region. They may put up three, but in essence there is only one in the west that will be appointed as a tenderer. The nomination of the Garden Island dockyard is just a fiction because Garden Island does not do submarine overhauls. It is in the process of being privatised at the moment. It cannot even maintain the surface ships that it is responsible for for the Royal Australian Navy. It has farmed some of those out to Cockatoo Island. There is no way it can undertake to overhaul the intermediate level docking of the Oberon boats. It is just a straw man put up to enable the Minister to claim that he is being fair in his usual way.

I do not intend to debate the Minister's allegations and assertions about the press releases in the gallery here, but those of us who are interested in defence are concerned at the way the Minister leans on the gallery. The point that he ought to recognise is that the most informed, most authoritative journalist in the country in defence matters, Peter Young, was driven out of employment covertly by this Government.

—Can the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) tell me what is the incidence of cases where the Child Support Agency makes payments to custodial parents through the Department of Social Security when it has not received any such payments from the non-custodial parent?

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an official here from the Child Support Agency. What I say should be taken as subject to confirmation. From my own recollection of the policy, where there is no payment at all from a non-custodial parent the custodial parent is entitled to the supporting parent's benefit. Where there is a payment from the non-custodial parent, after a free area of $6 or $12 a week the supporting parent's benefit payment is withdrawn at a rate of 50c for each dollar of payment by the non-custodial parent above the free area. I am sure that information would have been part of a press statement or a statement to the House by the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, at the time that that was the arrangement which would apply. There is a free area. I cannot remember off the top of my head whether it is $6 or $12 per child. Beyond that, any payment from the non-custodial parent induces a reduction in the supporting parent's benefit payment of 50c for every dollar of payment received from the non-custodial parent.

—If the non-custodial parent is not making the payments to the Agency the Department of Social Security continues to pay and through taxation or other means forces the non-custodial parent to pay up. Are there any outstanding payments not being made to the Child Support Agency? When that occurs what happens to the custodial parent? Do they have any penalty or is the full amount paid automatically by the Department of Social Security? How much is the outstanding debt?

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that the question is not very clear. I am relying on my own recollection of the Cabinet discussions of these matters, which goes back six to 12 months. Prior to the introduction of the present policy there were a number of Family Court orders on maintenance. Those maintenance payments affected the supporting parent's benefit entitlement that the custodial parent may have been entitled to receive. Since the Child Support Agency was established and the present policy was introduced, on a prospective basis-that is, for new applicants-there is a requirement that prior to receiving the supporting parent's benefit a custodial parent must make an application to receive maintenance through the CSA. That condition may be waived under certain circumstances, for example, where it is accepted that an attempt to recover a contribution from the non-custodial parent could endanger, in a physical sense, the custodial parent. I do not have the precise details. It is a social security matter rather than a Treasury and Taxation Office matter. There is a requirement under normal circumstances, but that requirement may under abnormal circumstances be waived, for a custodial parent to make an application to receive maintenance from the non-custodial parent as a prerequisite to receiving supporting parents benefit. Obviously there will be some people-I do not know the numbers-who are in receipt of a payment from a non-custodial parent, but if the payment is not sufficiently large to disqualify the custodial parent from the supporting parent's benefit, in those circumstances those custodial parents would receive a part supporting parent's benefit payment.

—I was told in the April Estimates hearings that there was a very long delay. My question related to the fact that a nine-week delay was incurred by the custodial parent joining the scheme from the time of registration with the Agency to the time of the receipt of first payment. I was told that this delay was caused by the problem of actually getting the money from the non-custodial parent-the gap between the time of the employer putting in the non-custodial parent payment and the time that it was passed through Social Security. That gave me the impression that the money was not paid to the custodial parent until it had actually been received by the Agency. Is that not correct?

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that that is correct-that if the CSA has not received money from the non-custodial parent, it does not and cannot pay it to the custodial parent. —Bearing that in mind, can the Minister say how much is outstanding to the Child Support Agency at present in terms of money unpaid by non-custodial parents?

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not know that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH

I shall try to obtain the information requested and notify Senator Walters by letter.

—I cite one case relating to the Child Support Agency involving a constituent who had been paying his maintenance on a regular basis, but who suddenly received an account for $1,000. He was told to pay up or else, when he was completely up to date with his payments. How many other people around Australia have complained of having had the same experience, and how is the Minister acting to prevent such things happening in future?

The custodial parents had failed to register-in other words, to notify the relevant department, which I presume would be Social Security and/or the Taxation Office-that there was a Family Court maintenance order in place.

—I thank the Minister for that answer, but I would point out that in the case I cited that was not the case. The first case involved a non-custodial parent where both parents had registered. The second case involved a custodial parent where both had once again registered, but on this occasion it was the custodial parent who was notified that she was owed over $3,000, when that was not the case. The lady in question was afraid that any harassment from a government department may have put a satisfactory arrangement in jeopardy. So once again I ask a further question: How can there possibly be only two cases when I know of more than two just in Western Australia? How many are occurring around this country?
