SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The resumption of debate on this important Migration Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 is welcome. Certainly, the period that has elapsed since the matter first came before the Senate has been properly utilised. Nonetheless, it has to be said that this Bill, and the amendments to which the Government has finally agreed after extensive negotiations with the Opposition and ethnic community groups, are a flawed response to the FitzGerald Commission to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies, which conducted the most comprehensive review of immigration in 10 years. It took nine months to examine the issues, consulted with 587 individuals and organisations, received 970 written submissions and held four workshops and commissioned 11 consultancies to advise it. It came up with a series of very specific and carefully thought out recommendations. I think it can be fairly said that in significant respects the Government has rejected those recommendations for what could be described as cheap electoral purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission quite rightly identified citizenship as the ultimate expression of a commitment to Australia. We in the Opposition wholeheartedly share that recognition. It is of crucial importance that all of those who reside within our borders have that fundamental commitment. They should recognise what is entailed in being an Australian citizen and should aspire to become one as soon as possible. The Government has accepted the core recommendation that immigration policies should be developed in the national interest for all Australians and that in the philosophy of immigration emphasis should be given to Australia, the Australian identity and a commitment to Australia. That is a very worthwhile and highly desirable commitment. The Government has also accepted a recommendation to develop and explain to the public a rationale for immigration, especially having regard to the international context in which immigration takes place. There is no doubt that there is a great deal of misunderstanding and confusion in the community as to some of the crucial ingredients in immigration policy.

The Government, however, has not accepted a recommendation to examine ways of restricting public benefits to non-citizens as a means of enhancing the value of citizenship. That recommendation was not made lightly by FitzGerald. That reflects an overwhelming view in the community that there should be a quid quo pro. If one is a resident of Australia one should actively seek to become a citizen and, to the extent that one chooses not to do so, then certain consequences should flow. To the extent that one will not otherwise be out on the streets, it seems reasonable to us that one should pay a pecuniary penalty for choosing not to accept Australian citizenship.

Perhaps the most crucial recommendation of all which the Government has studiously ignored is the recommendation to increase the total quota intake to 150,000. I believe it has done that because it has really been pandering to a constituency in this country that still shares the old shibboleths about--

TALK.START.PARA: —Nick Greiner is supporting us.

—He may be but that does not affect the principle of the issue. For my money, there are very significant economic benefits that flow from an increased immigration intake. I do not regard going from 140,000 to 150,000 as a huge leap. But I do believe it would be a very useful way of signalling to the rest of the world that Australia is prepared to increase its intake even though we have significant levels of unemployment, that we do recognise the very great contribution that has been made to social cohesion and the welfare of the nation by an immigration policy that has seen about 4.7 million people come to this country since 1949.

SPEECH.PARA: It would have been a very symbolic gesture to have made that increase-one that would not have threatened the infrastructure of the nation, which is one of the explanations given for not taking that leap. Also, in many ways it would have enabled the Government to adopt another very significant recommendation of FitzGerald-that is, to place emphasis on skills and entrepreneurial factors. To the extent that FitzGerald recommended that the highest weightings go to those factors, the Government has again chosen to disregard that recommendation. An increase to 150,000 would have allowed the Government to increase the economic component of the intake, maintain the family relationship and refugee components, although as a reduced proportion of the total. That would have suited everyone in the community. Again it is a sign of timidity on the part of the Government that it has not been prepared to bite the bullet in these areas.

The further recommendation that entitlement to sponsor immigrants including kinship should be limited to Australian citizens was once again disregarded by the Government. All in all, one can say that the Government has shown an abundance of caution. Indeed, Dr FitzGerald, in the Sunday Telegraph, was very concerned about the highly political approach that the Government had taken. He even said that there had been a deliberate campaign aimed at discrediting the report. He attributed that to persons, one of whom was on the Prime Minister's personal staff and another of whom was a senior officer in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. Dr FitzGerald made no bones about saying that they prepared a document which was simply for the purpose of scaring the pants off most of the ethnic community. He described it as one of the most mendacious documents he had ever seen in government and that is pretty strong language from one who was formerly an ambassador and is universally well regarded in the Australian community.

He certainly gives the Government high praise for adopting the floating pass mark to replace the old fixed points system. I think we all share the view that that is a change that is welcome and will allow for more flexibility but ultimately keep a cap on the intake so that governments remain in control of the numbers and that is very important change for the better. Dr FitzGerald was critical of the Government's decision to reject the recommendation that it is necessary to speak English. He did say:
I think that is unfortunate. I think it's wrong. People talk about all these people who came out from Greece or wherever in 1950 and became a great entrepreneur and all that, but times change.

It is yet another indication that the Government has not been prepared to act on what I think are very sensible recommendations. We take the view that the Government has walked away from the major recommendations of the FitzGerald report and not placed sufficient emphasis on skills and investment criteria and, indeed, by not increasing the intake in the way that I have indicated, it has shown that it is not really prepared to expand and regard immigration policy as an opportunity to increase economic growth; it is essentially a holding operation aimed at pandering to various sectional interests in the community. To that extent it is lacking in foresight.

The ultimate response as reflected in the Bills does contain a number of positive aspects and I would like to deal with several of them. We welcome the Government's ultimate decision to retain in the Minister the discretion to make the ultimate decision on who should enter this country and who should remain here. As the Minister said previously, it is necessary to detach final decisions from political influence but, at the end of the day, there are some decisions the Government simply cannot shirk. It is a responsibility of the Government, not the bureaucracy, and there are and always will be hard cases. I recall its being said by a renowned Englishman, whose name escapes me for the moment, that a tax system breathes through its loopholes. One could say the same about immigration policy. It is necessary to have those areas of discretion to accommodate the hard cases that simply do not show up in the official rule book. Unless we are prepared to accept the ultimate political responsibility, we are in the wrong kitchen. It has been a change for the better that the Minister, to his credit, has been prepared to rethink the matter and to have the discretion vest where it ought to vest and not be devolved to bureaucrats, who should not be put in the invidious position of having to make hard decisions. Ultimately, the outcome in that area is welcome and will be a significant change for the better.

I think it is fair to say that there is a radically revised approach to immigration decision-making. It is one that we welcome. The proposed codification of the decision-making process to determine the composition of the intake is desirable. It is important that policies be laid down to govern the rules for entry and stay in Australia. As long as the Minister is the one who shares ultimate responsibility for those decisions, we support that approach.

The new two-tier system of review similarly is one we welcome. The concept of having a first stage review by specialist officers of the Department is desirable and worth supporting. The second tier-the review by the Immigration Review Tribunal-is more controversial, to the extent that although persons will not be legally represented before the Tribunal, there will not be the traditional adversarial approach. That is something that, at this stage, we are prepared to take on trial. We take the view, I think, that a great deal of time, resources and money can be spent in an area where, if decision-making is seen to be too lax or even too complicated, persons can be encouraged to come to Australia and test that very process. It is something that should be of concern to us. To a certain extent there is a demonstration effect that will flow from what is a fairly peremptory approach but nonetheless one that does deserve our support at this stage.

As to the rules regarding the total intake, again we recognise the virtues of having a floating points system. The balance of family test for families wanting to migrate to Australia is a desirable innovation and, as the Minister has pointed out, the costs of the current arrangements are very significant indeed, parents constituting something like 9 per cent of the total migration of families. Sixty per cent of those parents of working age coming here are unemployed. People of age 45 and over are generally very hard to find employment for, and the balance of family test is said to save some $300m. We do regard that as a very significant amount and, hopefully, the change will mean that those who do come here will be much less dependent upon the Australian welfare system.

The entitlement to an interpreter in line with the approach adopted by the Social Security Review Tribunal is similarly welcome. The decision to extend the time limit to ensure that time does not run out when an appeal is part heard before a federal court is, I would have thought, plain common sense. The decision to allow an additional period if the applicant is overseas is again desirable and to be welcomed. The restructuring of the intake to provide for two categories of family-priority family and concessional family-again, whilst it is a departure from the recommendations of FitzGerald, is ultimately something that we would be happy to accommodate, certainly to the extent that caps will be put in place in each of the categories. We see that as desirable.

We welcome the Minister's decision to establish a joint select committee which will be charged with considering the regulations which will prescribe decision criteria for the grant of visas and entry permits, and will examine whether those regulations reflect current and announced policies. As a result of a suggestion put by my colleague Mr Ruddock, the Government has also given the committee extensive powers of subpoena and production of documents. Again that is very necessary and we are confident that the committee will ensure that the regulations are not abused. Because of the sunset clauses, it will not be there in perpetuity but will be able to scrutinise closely while still allowing the Government the flexibility that is necessary to remain in control of the immigration program.

The Opposition welcomes the amended Bill and, indeed, the package. We look forward to the Minister moving the amendments in the form that he has foreshadowed and certainly of which I have a copy. I will leave it to him to spell out the details of those amendments. Essentially they go a long way to meet our concerns in the area. As a result we will have a Migration Act that will provide the necessary flexibility that will improve quite considerably on some of the procedures that were becoming outdated but will nonetheless do substantial justice to those wanting to come to this country.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Abortion-Grand Opera Concert: Parliament House-Death of Mr David Gundy

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak for a few minutes about the formation of a pro-choice group of parliamentarians in the Federal Parliament. It is not a matter that I expected to be speaking about. I feel, like most people in the Parliament with reasonable common sense, that it is an issue I do not want to be actively involved in. However, in view of the fact that it has been announced that the so-called Pro-Life Group is now looking at seeking to move a motion or amend the Medicare legislation to eliminate the right of women, particularly poor women, to have legal abortions conducted and paid for under Medicare, many members of the Parliament have thought it necessary to form what we call a pro-choice group so that the issue does not lapse by default and so that the willingness of many people in the community who strongly oppose the views of the so-called Pro-Life Group can have an actively organised voice in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, our group did not seek to be formed of our own volition. We openly admit that we are a reactive group, that we have formed in reaction to the publicity that has occurred over the last few weeks about the so-called Pro-Life Group. I mention in particular the efforts instigated by my colleague the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, who took the first step in outlining to all Federal Labor members the need to form a pro-choice group. Already there has been an excellent response. Many Labor members from both Houses-within the lexicon of the Labor Party, from all factions-have indicated that they will support this group.

We held our first meeting last week. We decided to write to all members of parliament and invite them to indicate whether they want to join a pro-choice group in the Federal Parliament. Although the letter was sent only at the end of last week and this is the first sitting day after the weekend, there has already been formal indication that members of other political parties would be willing to join a pro-choice group on this issue. Although we are not in the head counting business-I know some people may suggest that Senator Robert Ray and I have been known to count the occasional head in the past-in this case it is not a matter of counting every head in the Parliament and lining people up as being either pro-choice or so-called pro-life. The issue is far too important to be treated in that way. We want it to be known that we are interested in the issue, in ensuring that ordinary Australian women who make the choice, as is their right in accordance with the laws of the land, to have a termination of pregnancy have the support of Medicare funding.

I do not intend to debate the merits of the issue at this time. It has been debated many times before and I am sure it will be debated in the near future if the so-called Pro-Life Group introduces its legislation. The only thing I put to the Senate-this is why I am now acting as a co-convener for the pro-choice group-is that I believe abortion is a matter for the woman to decide. Whatever she chooses-if she chooses to have the baby, if she chooses not to have the baby and to have an abortion in accordance with the laws of the land-she should be given every support. In the past this issue has been dominated by moralising men who choose to ram down the throats of women what they think should happen to their bodies. I believe that in this part of the twentieth century that attitude should not be taken. I believe that our pro-choice group will perform a valuable role in countering some of the, in my view, misleading information, misleading arguments and, above all, some of the more emotional comments made by members of the so-called Pro-Life Group.

As I discovered last Thursday night in attempting to debate this issue with Senator Harradine on a television program, the debate very quickly degenerates into remarks about murder of the unborn child, babies being cut up, suction pumps and goodness knows what else. In my view, it is all totally unnecessary. The remarks are aimed at putting psychological pressure on women. I refer in particular to the emotional charge that women flippantly decide to have an abortion. I cannot imagine any woman in Australia flippantly deciding that it would be good fun to have an abortion. I must admit that I know a couple of women who have chosen to have an abortion. They did it legally, after consultation with the appropriate medical authorities, and they certainly did not do it, as Senator Harradine suggested on television, so that they could have a trip overseas or because it interfered with their holiday plans. I completely reject the idea that abortion is used by women in a flippant and offhand way. That suggestion denigrates all women in Australia.

In that televised debate, in response to Senator Harradine's remarks about murder, I said that if he believes abortion is murder, he and his supporters should be fair dinkum and attempt to introduce legislation to the effect that when a woman has an abortion she is committing the offence of murder under the criminal code. If one extended that one would have to argue that if a woman had a miscarriage she may have to be charged with manslaughter-if one takes the view that she is murdering the unborn child and that that is the same as murdering someone after he or she has been born. I do not accept that. I do not think that is accepted anywhere in the Western world. I certainly hope it is not. I hope our pro-choice group can help to put that argument to the community.

One of the other reasons I wanted to speak about this matter tonight is that while the pro-choice group was having its first meeting last Tuesday, a meeting of the Pro-Life Group took place in Parliament House. The details of that discussion have come to my attention. Sources have given me a very detailed run-down of the discussion that took place in that meeting at about 5 o'clock last Tuesday. People in the so-called Pro-Life Group argue that they are interested in the issue on a very high moral plane. In regard to the details of the discussion that took place, one would not exactly say that it was a grubby political exercise, but it was certainly a very mundane political exercise. The meeting tried to sort out the tactics as to how the group could introduce legislation into the Federal Parliament to stop Medicare funding for legal abortions. First of all, I do not know all of those who attended, but obviously one would expect Senator Harradine to have been there as Chairman of the Pro-Life Group. As I understand it, members of all political parties attended. I do not deny their right to hold what are, in their terms, very strong moral views concerning abortion. My group does not in any way decry the fact that there are strongly held views about abortion. However, our attitude is that those views should be held at a personal level and should not be imposed on others through legislation, at either State or Federal level.

Even allowing for the fact that people in the Pro-Life Group have very strong views, some of their remarks and comments and discussions are rather illuminating, according to my sources. First, a number of people had a very strong desire to ensure that no information about their meeting would leak out. That had happened after the previous meeting and had caused them some embarrassment, and they had to make absolutely sure that there was no leak from this one. Unfortunately for them, they did not do too well in that regard. From my sources, I have some pretty detailed discussion.

First, they discussed some of the arguments that could be used in favour of their proposition. One of those was that abortion should not be available to women because in Australia there are many people who want to adopt children. The point was made that if women-young girls, in particular-who, unfortunately, became pregnant had to continue with the pregnancy, there would be a much bigger pool of babies available for adoption. One person at the meeting commented that one million people out there wanted to adopt children. They would not care whether a child was Australian, Vietnamese or of any other origin. I must say that that is a very strange attitude from people who are supposed to be adopting a very moral position about abortion. It is not a particularly moral or a very uplifting sort of argument.

According to my sources, one of the discussions that took place at this meeting concerned tactics: `If we are successful in having legislation passed to remove Medicare payments, there will be a lot more unwanted children'. One member said, `We have to have an absolutely foolproof oversupply of pregnancy support services'. Another member present-it may have been Senator Harradine-said, `I cannot follow the argument. I donate to pregnancy support all the time'. The argument continued. Other members said that they could not go round saying nice things about supporting pregnant girls if there were no pregnancy support facilities.

Then the attention of the meeting turned to tactics-whether the Bill could be introduced before the Parliament rose for the winter recess. I understand that, according to Senator Harradine, the main tactic was that when Parliament went into recess there could be a massive campaign, with petitions, and so on, and that the group could expect enormous support in the community. This, again, is an example of anticipation that those in the community who support the right to life will be expected to put a lot of pressure on members of parliament about the way they should vote. It was suggested also that the period leading up to an election would be a more advantageous time to put pressure on. Again, that is not a very morally uplifting argument about the issue of abortion. It is a straight political argument about how to apply the greatest pressure.

One of the more interesting side issues that arose in the course of the discussion concerned whether legislation should be introduced in the House of Representatives or in the Senate. One member present commented that if it were to be done in the Senate, they would have to wait until after the next election, when half the Democrats would be got rid of. I think that that member hoped that the Democrats would be decimated, that they would be replaced by people more sympathetic to the so-called Pro-Life view. I do not know what the Democrats' view-individually or collectively-about this legislation is, though I presume that theirs is a conscience vote. It is interesting to note, however, that already the Pro-Life Group is counting all the Democrats in the Senate as being against them on this issue.

Then the discussion got round to the good old question of numbers. In the past I have been accused within the Labor Party of occasionally counting numbers. So has Senator Robert Ray. Indeed, I think that everybody in politics has counted numbers from time to time. It is part and parcel of the whole arrangement. However, the information that I have indicates that this mob is not very good at counting. At the very best, they were able to count only one or two people. They had a circuitous discussion about the numbers in the House of Representatives. At one stage they talked about some of the women there. Kathy Martin was accused of being a bit soft on the proposition. Nobody was sure what Mary Crawford's view was. Generally, however, the women in the House of Representatives were considered not to be reliable from the point of view of supporting the Pro-Life Group. Mr Katter, a long-time member of the House of Representatives, was at the meeting.
I have just been handed a note. I should not be interrupted by a written interjection from the Minister, but I shall keep it in my personal records for the future.

Mr Katter talked about how, way back at the time of the so-called Lamb-McKenzie amendments in 1973, there was an enormous lobby campaign-telegrams to everybody, and so on-and about how successful it had been. Even on the basis of their own head count, these people were extremely unsure about their numbers. After a lengthy meeting, they could not decide whether it would be better to introduce legislation in the House of Representatives or in the Senate.

The discussion came round to the question of which member should introduce the legislation if it were to be introduced in the House of Representatives. The name of a colleague of mine-David Charles, the member for Isaacs, and a member of the Pro-Life Group, who was not at the meeting-was immediately thrown up. I suspect that that was because he was not at the meeting to reject the advances. The main reason that was put forward was that David had already announced that he would not stand at the next election. In that case he could be the bunny to introduce the legislation or the amendment in the lower House.

It was then realised that Mr Katter might be thinking of retiring. He was asked whether he would do it, but he equivocated. I think that he is still weighing up whether to run again. It is interesting that even these pro-life advocates are looking for somebody who will not be standing at the next election. They do not want somebody to take the heat of putting up the proposition either in this chamber or in the House of Representatives. Again, the way in which the matter has been handled is not particularly morally uplifting; it is down to simple tactics.

Then the discussion got round to the role of Senator Michael Tate, who is a member of the Pro-Life Group. I gather that, at the meeting, there was certainly some bad spleen vented about the way Senator Tate had refused to go along with the proposal to introduce amendments to stop Medicare payments. Since then, Senator Tate has published a letter and made statements to the effect that, although he has a pro-life view, he wants women to be able to choose not to have abortions. He has indicated that if any amendment or legislation is introduced into the Parliament by the Pro-Life Group, he will vote against it. There have been several suggestions that a deputation should go to see Senator Tate to try to convince him to return to what I suppose Senator Harradine would call the fold of the true believers.

There is a final interesting comment on the meeting that took place. During one of the intense parts of the discussion Senator Bjelke-Petersen entered the room and asked if anyone had seen her book. The meeting was diverted into trying to find Senator Bjelke-Petersen's book. She said that she had paid $5 for the book and wanted it returned. She then asked what had been decided. At that stage no-one could work out what had been decided. The meeting gradually petered out. From my source it is still not clear whether the group got anyone to move the amendments, either in this place or in the House of Representatives. Even if it got somebody, the nature of those amendments, resolutions or the legislation is still not clear. It is still not clear whether its members agree amongst themselves about the tactics they want to employ.

I thought I would bring all this information to the attention of the Senate tonight. I look forward to receiving more information about the next meeting of the so-called Pro-Life Group. I assure it that the Pro-Choice Group that has been formed is very open about its views and the way it wants to conduct itself. We are not too worried if there are leaks about our discussions or tactics. We hope that in the future, if the Pro-Life Group wishes to proceed, it should not have an obsession with secrecy or the working out of what, in my view, are pretty ordinary political tactics. It should not put pressure upon people to try to bluff legislation through this Parliament.

In conclusion, all I say is that, from all the indications so far, I do not believe that a majority of the Australian Parliament, in either chamber, will vote for this legislation or proposal, whatever it may be. I think there are more than enough people in all parties to make sure that it is rejected. All the evidence from around Australia indicates, in all public opinion polls conducted on these sorts of issues, that 60 per cent to 70 per cent of Australian citizens support the right of women to have abortions under reasonable and certain conditions and support the right of poor women in particular to get Medicare payments. I trust that the so-called Pro-Life Group will realise the error of its ways and will not bring what will be a divisive and unnecessary issue on to the floor of Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will have no difficulty remembering the recent extraordinary assault by New South Wales police officers on the home of Mr David Gundy and his family, leading to the awakening of Mr Gundy and the discharge of one or more firearm blasts which left the victim mortally wounded and his bed covered with blood. According to news reports, Mr Gundy died within an hour of the shooting incident. It is to be hoped that on 10 July, when Mr Kevin Waller, the State Coroner for New South Wales, commences the inquest into Mr Gundy's death, he will be able to examine all available evidence and testimony in the course of arriving at a finding which does justice to all concerned. The Australian coronial system is very much in the spotlight at the moment, and Justice Muirhead and many others have certainly found it wanting and have criticised it.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been reported that only seconds before Mr Gundy was fatally shot, he was asleep in his own bed in his own home. He should have been safe. Because of an imputed connection with a wanted man, 10 policemen smashed down his front door, broke into his home and entered carrying shotguns and other weapons. No-one is at their best at 4.50 in the morning, especially after having been woken in the manner in which David Gundy was. The police said he struggled with them and was accidentally shot. It is less than surprising that almost any family man would struggle with an unidentified person carrying a firearm who had broken down his front door at 4.50 in the morning.

The Southern Crime Squad Commander, Detective Superintendent Ronald Stephenson, was quoted in the Daily Telegraph of Friday, 28 April, as having said that although Mr Gundy was not a suspect, he was satisfied that the police had acted properly during the raid. This was despite the fact that Mr Gundy was unarmed and no weapons were found in his home. No doubt at the inquest the Southern Crime Squad Commander can explain how the death of an innocent man at the hands of the police can be called `acting properly', when our legislation has not given even the courts the power of life and death.

From press reports it appears that the police account of the shooting conflicts with that of Mr Gundy's young son Bradley, who was asleep in the house at the time of the raid. He was woken by the noise of loud banging and was escorted from his room to the lounge and then to the kitchen, together with his uncle. Bradley was unaware of the events that took his father's life. He heard no gun shots or struggle. Bradley said he learned of his father's death from a television news broadcast later that day after being escorted by police from his home to stay with relatives. Mr Pickering, the New South Wales Minister for Police, is recorded as saying that he was concerned at the death but that he understood that the police could possibly be feeling uptight after the earlier shooting of two policemen. It makes me wonder how uptight the Aboriginal community was feeling after Mr Gundy's sudden demise.

It now remains for the State Coroner to inquire into the full facts and circumstances and, I repeat, I sincerely trust that he will be in a position to do so impartially and without the sort of hindrance that was placed on the Western Australian Coroner, Mr David McCann, when 17 police officers declined to provide testimony at the inquest into the death of Stephen Wardle. Stephen's parents, Mr and Mrs Ross Tilbury, have had to ask for a royal commission into their son's death in order for the full facts of the circumstances of his death to be revealed.

I call on the Government of New South Wales to accept responsibility for the ongoing expenses relating to the education and well-being of Mr Gundy's son Bradley, who has been left without a father. The Apex organisation is to be commended for having instituted a fund for the family. However, the Apex fund should not be used as an excuse for the Government to evade its full duty towards this young boy. The Apex fund must be considered as supplementary to full Government support.

On Wednesday, 31 May, there will be marches in some Australian cities in support of the Gundy family and I believe that there will be one in Perth. They certainly have my support, and my sympathy goes out to the Gundy family.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 29 November 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Had the Foundation for Aboriginal Affairs, an organisation based in New South Wales, received approximately $900,000 in public funds up to the time of its liquidation.
(2) Was the Foundation the subject of an investigation in 1976 which found serious examples of mismanagement and impropriety in its affairs.
(3) Will the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs table a copy of the 1976 report in the Parliament.
(4) What was the nature of Charles Perkins' and Phillip Hall's association with the Foundation.

(5) At the time of the liquidation of the Foundation, did the following Aboriginal organisations receive, disbursements from the realisation of the assets of the Foundation: Western District Foundation for Aboriginals, Aboriginal Medical Service, Redfern, Aboriginal Housing Company, Redfern, Aboriginal Legal Service, Redfern, Murawina, Redfern, Aboriginal Children's Service, Awabakal, Aboriginal Corporation, Newcastle, New England Aboriginal Corporation, Armidale, South Sydney Community Aid (Funeral Fund), and St Marys and District Aboriginal Legal Service.
(6) In the period 1979-1982, did Mr Phillip Hall represent himself to the office bearers to the above organisations as an `agent' arranging the disbursement mentioned in (5) above.
(7) Did Mr Phillip Hall demand, and receive, a `fee' from each of the above organisations in return for his arranging the disbursement to each organisation.

(8) In particular, does the Minister or his Department have information establishing that Mr Phillip Hall demanded from the New England Aboriginal Corporation a `fee' of $3,000, and that he received from the Corporation, an amount of $2890 wired from the Armidale post office on 15 October 1982 to the Woden post office in the Australian Capital Territory.
(9) Has the Minister's Department established what `fees' Mr Phillip Hall has, or may have received, from any other of the organisations listed in (5) above.
(10) Has any aspect of this matter been reported to the police; if so, with what result.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following response:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Foundation for Aboriginal Affairs (the Foundation) was incorporated in New South Wales in December 1964 and was placed in liquidation in May 1976. During this period it is likely the Foundation would have received public funds from a number of sources. I am not in a position to estimate the total amount.

The Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) has informed me that from its records it cannot verify a total amount provided by DAA and the former Officer of Aboriginal Affairs, although it would appear that it could be somewhat less than $900,000.
(2) and (3) On 13 October 1975 the Foundation agreed to an inquiry into its management and operation which had been requested by the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

The confidential report of the DAA inquiry was provided to the new Government in December 1975. I am informed by DAA that the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the Hon. Ian Viner, considered and acted upon the Report.
In the circumstances, I do not intend to table a copy.
(4) DAA does not have (nor should it) a detailed record of association of Mr Perkins and Mr Hall with the Foundation.

It is a matter of public record, however, that Mr Perkins played a significant role in the incorporation of the Foundation and he was involved in the early management of its affairs. He is listed as a subscriber in the Memorandum of Association of the Company, together with the then Lord Mayor of Sydney, a retired Deputy Commissioner of police, two academics, a nursing sister and an accountant.

In 1980, he was appointed by a judge in the New South Wales Supreme Court to represent members of the Foundation in the distribution of surplus assets and, in this regard, to bring forward a draft scheme applying such assets cy-pres, before the Master of Equity.

Whatever other association Mr Hall may have had with the Foundation it would appear that he served as President for a short period from December 1974 and was appointed General Manager in April 1975. It is apparent that his services were utilised in the development of the draft disbursement scheme referred to above.
(5) In May 1982 the Master in Equity in the NSW Supreme Court brought down a judgment which provided for disbursements by the liquidator to the organisations listed.

(6) and (7) I am informed by DAA that it has no information on its files which would determine how Mr Hall represented himself to each of the organisations in regard to his role in developing the disbursement scheme nor whether he had demanded and received a fee from each of the organisations for his services.

(8) On 3 December 1982 the New England Aboriginal Corporation informed DAA that it had made a payment of $2,890 to Mr Hall from its disbursement and provided a receipt, which it claimed supported the allegation. It also forwarded an unsworn statement which included the allegation that Mr Hall had requested the payment of $3,000 for his work and had sought a similar amount from Aboriginal organisations outside Sydney which had received the disbursements.

(10) The documents provided by the New England Aboriginal Corporation were provided to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) which informed DAA that the matter was for consideration by the New South Wales police. The New England Aboriginal Corporation was informed of the AFP advice and its documents were returned should it wish to pursue its allegations with the State Police authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 11 May 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it correct that if blind persons working in sheltered workshops have to go on workers' compensation, then the total value of any payments they are receiving, such as sheltered employment allowances and/or a spouse's invalid pension, are subsequently reduced by the amount of their worker's compensation payment, resulting in anything up to a 50 per cent reduction in their total household income; if so, can this situation be justified on the grounds of equity and fairness, which underlie our Social Security system, or is this simply an anomaly in the legislation;
(2) If this is an anomaly, will the Government be taking steps to rectify it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The effect of workers' compensation on blind recipients of sheltered employment allowance or invalid pension is no different from the effect on other invalid pensioners or sheltered employment allowees.

Successive Governments have maintained the principle of employer or insurer responsibility for work-related illness or injury. Hence, the exemption of permanently blind people from the income and assets tests otherwise applied to invalid pensioners and sheltered employment allowees, does not extend to exemption from the compensation deduction, preclusion and recovery provisions of the Social Security Act.
